reviewText: I've tried countless Bluetooth headsets since 2000 with Jabra.  Since then I've tried numerous models, some good, some bad (some real bad).  When the original iPhone came out in 2007, my hunt for a good Bluetooth headset got more serious.  I've tried many of them (Jabra, Morotola, Lubix, Jawbone, Plantronics, etc.) and wasn't happy with any of them.  My last one was Plantronics 975 because I gave up finding a stereo headset that I could be happy with.  It was okay for calls...it was small but I'm not one of those that parade around with a headset in my ear all day, so I had to always find a place to keep it handy to answer calls (and no I didn't want to use a lanyard)So while perusing Amazon last week, I came across this one by chance (honestly I didn't know LG even made them).  I immediately ordered one and got it very next day.  After using it for almost a week, both indoors and outdoors, I have to put this one on top of my list of all time favorite list.  Here are the pluses:- Since all the weight is in the housing that goes around your neck, only thing that goes into your ears is the buds so it's very light and comfortable to have it on.- It comes with 2 sets of ear buds.  I had to use the larger ones for more snug fit.- The whole unit is still light so right after putting this around your neck, you forget you have it around you (funny, this is also a minue).- Works great with Siri (was my biggest concern)- Reception is very good.  I can walk from my home office to the kitchen (~35ft and two walls) and still can have a conversation.- You don't have to memorize a series of complex sequences to use the controls.  It comes with a separate on/off slidern switch, volume up/down, call/answer button (you also use this to invoke Siri) on the left side.  On the right has play/pause button and prev/next track controls.  It only took me 15 minutes to get familar with these controls.- The unit is very comfortable and flexible.- More opportunity to listen to your music without worrying about missing calls...plus you don't look weird wearing it because they look more like stereo music headphones.- It's sleek and easy to conceal it under the collar of your collared shirt.  Just the ends will produce slightly.- The earbuds are magnetized so they snaps into the end of the housing.Now the minuses:- It's so comfortable and light that you forget you have them on. especially when you have the buds stored.- The microphone is located in the left side near the end, so when you have the buds stored it, it blocked by it.- I wish I can turn off the small blue light ring (around the call button).  It does attract attention especially indoors.- If you push the call button slightly longer, it redials the last number (called my boss a couple times...embarrasing).  I wish they made it a little longer.- It does not have noise-cancellation so when using it outdoors, Siri sometime didn't work as expected (but Siri is still Beta).All in all, I'm very happy with this unit.  I think this is by far the best bluetooth headsets you can have for your iPhone 4S.  I highly recommend it.
title: LG Tone Wireless Bluetooth Stereo Headset - Retail Packaging - Black/Orange
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Headsets', 'Bluetooth Headsets'], ['Electronics', 'Accessories & Supplies', 'Audio & Video Accessories']]

reviewText: These are excellent earbuds.  The sound is very good.  The BlueTooth connection was simple to connect and the connection is strong.  With my other BT earbuds and headphones, I often loose the connection.  These LG's haven't cut out once in the 6 weeks or so tat I have been using them  The controls are easy to access for even someone like me who has very big fingers.I think the only real complaint I have is a little one.  Aside from having big hands, I have a large neck.  The device around the neck takes a little to get used to.  It's a little snug but not horrible.The charge last for days of about 2-3 hours usage a day.  Everyone I've spoken to while using them says that my voice is loud and clear.Overall, I am very happy with them and would certainly recommend them to anyone.

reviewText: I have bought and discarded quite a few bluetooth headphones over the least year. Each one having issues that makes them almost unusable to me. This LG HBS-700 set has surprised me by being near perfect for me. I can hide it under my collar, or under my over shirt so it is almost invisible. It has an excellent battery life. I can listen to my audio books all day, and it hasn't died on me yet. It never fails to connect, and has excellent audio quality.My only gripes are the flashing light, and the ear bud tips don't fit my ear correctly. The light has been fixed by a piece of electrical tape over the button (which does make the button a bit harder to use, but it's not bad) and the second issue is fixed by merely putting a larger tip on the ear bud. I happened to have some tips from an older set of skull candy ear buds I had laying around, and now they work great for me. Both negatives are easily fixed, and weren't a huge deal in the first place.If I ever break these, I'm ordering another pair.

reviewText: This is actually the second pair of BT earphones I've purchased.  It was a gift for my wife for when she takes her afternoon walks.  She never has to hold her iPhone and have an annoying wire flailing about.  She just keeps her phone in her pocket and kick out that playlist.  It is so comfortable to wear that sometimes you just wanna keep using it until the battery dies, but that's not a problem.  This pair of headsets lasts forever on a light to moderate use. I've also recommended this to a few of my colleagues and they swear they'll never buy another pair of BT headset but the LG HBS-700.  I'm looking to purchase another one just in case. reviewText: I've had these headphones on my Wish List for some time and finally received them for Christmas this year, and let me tell you something: I had NO idea what I was missing! If I'd realized how great these were, I would have purchased them for myself a long time ago.In the few days I have had them, I've easily used them for several multi-hour sessions (watching movies at night on my Tablet or music on my phone) with NO discomfort. In fact, I find it difficult to find earbuds small enough to comfortably fit my ears for more than a half an hour, but the default installed earbuds fit perfectly! (There is a second, larger set included).On top of that, at night I put on a movie or show on Netflix to fall asleep to, but wear headphones so as to not wake my spouse. Prior to receiving these, my favorite set have been a wired set of Vizio, which, if I rolled to my side, would become uncomfortable in the ear pressed into my pillow, and are often yanked out as the wire would get tangled up as I rolled around in my sleep.These have such a low profile in the ear that there is no pressure or discomfort when laying on my side. Even more impressive is that they remain in place even after moving around in my sleep. I just remove them on my first arousal after falling asleep. Even after using them the night before, I can use them the following day for several hours before recharging them for the next night.Ultimately, I returned this pair (HSB-700) for the similarly (and through some Amazon vendors, even more cheaply) priced Tone+ (HSB-730). I was stunned that the 700 does not include a microphone Mute function on the headset. There are a lot of very convenient control buttons, but found this to be an odd oversight. The HSB-730 includes a microphone mute, a vibration setting, and an increase to the already impressive battery life.PROs:+Extremely comfortable.+Good sound quality.+Great range.+Impressive battery life.+FANTASTIC VALUENEUTRAL:=The thin wire connecting the earbuds to the base may not be as durable long-term as some heavier-duty wired earbuds.=SMS Text Reader app was not personally tested, but Android Play Store reviews seem to indicate that the required app is hit or miss based on your specific device.CONs:-Surprising lack of a microphone mute feature.-Obsolete? Improved model available for the same price range.
title: LG Tone Wireless Bluetooth Stereo Headset - Retail Packaging - Black/Orange

reviewText: The LG Tone HBS-700 is a very comfortable set of bluetooth headphones. I would purchase them on this feature alone. The battery life is excellent allowing you to use the headphones for an entire workday. They have a small operating range beginning to drop out at approximately 15 feet (not the range I have gotten on similar devices) and this will cause problems with many devices that simply reconnecting will not always fix. All that aside, I've never worn a more comfortable and better sounding bluetooth audio device.However, it has a flaw.The microphone is the weakest point on the device. It clear but has very poor gain. The result is that you will be hard to hear on any phone calls you take with this device. The microphone also drops out on occasion and that can be annoying on long calls. While the sound is clear and sharp it is very very very faint. This one critical flaw has me looking for a second device to use for phone calls, one with a better microphone.All said, I'm happy with the purchase but I'm looking for a different device for managing phone calls. I would appreciate a similarly designed device with a boom microphone I could place next to my mouth.
title: LG Tone Wireless Bluetooth Stereo Headset - Retail Packaging - Black/Orange
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Headsets', 'Bluetooth Headsets'], ['Electronics', 'Accessories & Supplies', 'Audio & Video Accessories']]

reviewText: I purchased this phone for use as a backup/spare phone, in case my fancy schmancy Android phone goes out of whack. For $35, it's not too shabby. It costs $50+ with shipping anywhere else, so this was a great deal on Amazon by shopcelldeals.The touch screen is pretty sensitive, it doesn't require a lot of hard pressing unless you encounter a tiny object that needs a bit of accuracy. It uses a resistive touch screen, so it's not going to be comparable to a capacitive touch screen found on fancy touch screen phones, like Android phones and iPhone/iPod touch/iPads. I found it very surprising that the screen was so sensitive; from my previous experience with resistive touch screens, they require me to jam my thumb down on the screen to operate, but this phone had no trouble with the touch operation at all. Using the virtual QWERTY keyboard at first was a bit hard for me since I use an Android phone and an iPod touch 4G, but after getting used to the touch screen, it was easy to type.The features on this phone are quite fulfilling. There are a few smartphone-esque features on this phone, such as a home screen with widgets, a lock screen (sort of), and apps/games capability. The web browser appears to be a full HTML browser; it's easy to navigate around the web, but there is no video streaming capability (YouTube). The music player is pretty good on this device, it scans for all the songs you downloaded to the phone/memory card, and compiles them into a list. The speaker is loud and clear, a lot louder than my Android phone (10/20 volume on this phone is louder than full volume on my Android phone), so this phone is great for anyone who likes to use their phone as a boombox/stereo.The phone comes preloaded with 2 games, Container Block and Castle Defense. Container Block is quite entertaining, you have to find ways to move your container out of the area by moving other containers out of the way. I haven't played Castle Defense yet, but I'm sure it will be just as fun. You can download Java (J2ME) apps onto this phone, by either using the built-in web browser to download directly from app distribution sites, or transfer .jar files to your phone/memory card, then opening the file on the phone. You can use websites such as GetJar, MobileRated, etc. to get apps and games. The games won't be as fancy as smartphone games, but there are some classic games such as Tic Tac Toe, Tetris, and Pac-Man that you can play. I would recommend downloading Opera Mini so you can browse the web better, because the built-in web browser has a few issues with memory and doesn't have some of the features found in Opera Mini.The camera will get the job done for occasional snapshots on-the-go. It's a 2 megapixel camera, so don't expect it to take SLR quality pictures or videos. It also doesn't have an LED flash light, which is understandable since this is a low-end phone. Like any other cameras built into phones, it is horrible under low-lighting conditions, so it's best to just stick to taking pictures under bright light. In order to use the digital zoom option for taking photos, you would have to tune the size down to VGA quality (640x480). The video it records are somewhat decent; again, do not expect it to be high quality. The camera has a few settings such as brightness control, white balance, color effect, timer, continuous shot mode, night mode, etc. so you can shoot photos and videos with a few preferences.Now let's just get on with the miscellaneous stuff. The phone has common tools and utilities like calendar, alarm clock, calculator, tasks and memo pad, stop watch, world clock, voice recorder, and even a unit converter. There's two pages on the main menu, so be sure to swipe over to find the rest of the apps. The battery is a bit small, only holding 900mAh; it's not too bad since this isn't a fancy smartphone, it doesn't use as much power. The phone runs on AT&T; towers, and their EDGE service (theoretical max speed is around 240Kbps, most people only get around half of that). I get 4 to 5 bars most of the time at my house, so if you have good AT&T; reception at where you live, you're good to go. You can send and view MMS messages, so that's not a problem there. You can transfer contacts from another phone by either mashing them into a .vcf file, which is a feature found on most feature/smartphones; or you can transfer them to your phone via Bluetooth.This is a good feature/semi-smart phone for someone upgrading from another feature phone, or using it for a spare phone. It will get the job done if it fits your need, but don't expect it to be comparable to true smartphones (Android, iOS, Windows Phone, etc.)
title: LG 800G Prepaid Phone (Net10)
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Cell Phones', 'No-Contract Cell Phones', 'Phones']]

reviewText: I highly recommend this phone to anyone.  One of the best phones I have ever owned. I even got my Mom one of these and she dumped Verizon too. reviewText: The rating of this phone really depends on what you are looking for. If you are looking for an Android, look somewhere else. But if you are looking for something that is like a smartphone in some ways, this is the choice. Personally this is not something I would love and cherish, but if you don't want a fancy phone then this is a good idea. It has internet, texting, and you can download a facebook app. This in some ways is a more basic phone, because it cannot play Youtube videos, nor can it use wifi, and it doesn't have 3g or 4g speeds. And the thing is, it doesn't let you use the on-screen keyboard with the browser. I still can't understand why not, but trust me because of this you will get annoyed. You have to use the keypad, which is like when you dial a phone number, press 1 for letters a,b, or c. Press 2 for e,d, or f. You will find it can get quite annoying. The texting works well, and it does allow you to use the keyboard. You see, this is emulating Androids and iPhones because it has a virtual keyboard, not a slide-out one or anything like that.The facebook app can be tricky at times, and every time you use it you have to switch from the keypad to the keyboard. I don't understand why it just doesn't give you the keyboard to begin with. But maybe that is too much like an Android. There are a few useful things on this phone, like a stopwatch, alarm clock, unit converter, calculator, etc. While this may have the facebook app available, there are not many others. So if you want a phone with apps, do not get this one.Sometimes this phone can act weird, like sometimes the facebook app doesn't work, sometimes it acts weird during texting. I find that my signal goes up and down. Whenever it has all bars, it is fast. But when it has only a few bars, things are really slow. Battery life is okay, but there are plenty of other phones that get better battery life. There are a lot of cases available for this phone, which is a good thing. The touchscreen itself is okay, but not nearly as nice as an iPhone.So compared to an iPhone or any Android, this phone is a joke. But for someone who wants a cheap touchscreen, this is the one to get. The call reception is pretty good too. There are several plans available, all which you have to buy cards for. The most amount of minutes you can get is 750, but there is also an unlimited plan. But with this phone, that really seems like a waste of time. And you will find that the minutes go by fast, especially with texting.Update 5/13/2012I am so glad I switched to the LG Optimus. It may not be the best phone in the world at all, but at least it is better than this phone. I still have this phone, and I, just for the heck of it, turned it on. It's so inferior to an Android device. The minutes went by so quickly, I could never do the large amount of texting I do now. There is an unlimited plan, but why pay $50 for such a cheap device? There are plenty of far better prepaid phones out there for that amount or LESS! The touchscreen is terrible, even my Optimus has a better screen. In fact, its screen is very sensitive, I don't wish for it to be any more sensitive than it already is. But this phone, you cannot type fast, and you always have to turn the screen to use the keyboard. I would suggest you go with a slider phone instead, it is a much better option than this touchscreen. If you want a touchscreen, go with any Android from any prepaid carrier, there are some really nice ones out there, especially at MetroPCS.
title: LG 800G Prepaid Phone (Net10)
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Cell Phones', 'No-Contract Cell Phones', 'Phones']]

reviewText: I bought this for my husband while he was overseas on a deployment.  He loved it, and it really came in handy for him.  He used his American cell for an mp3 player with the data shut off (international just isn't worth it through Verizon).  He averaged over 10 hours a day of solid music playing without needing to plug his phone in.  If he wasn't listening to music much, the phone easily went a week between charges.  Definitely a must-have for people who don't want to charge their phones twice a day!The only downside is although it comes with the right battery cover, no company makes phone covers or skins that fit over the extended battery.  My husband had to choose between keeping his phone safe in an otterbox-esque cover or not having to charge the phone all day.  He chose the extended battery (he wasn't often near power outlets during the day) and was a bit more careful with his phone.Completely worth it, and he still uses it now that he's back home.  He loves it!

reviewText: I don't currently own this phone. Still, I've been able to sort of play with one for a few days. The processor is faster, so in stock form, is more user friendly compared to the V. Memory is still an issue, but like the V, if you only need a few apps, this shouldn't be a problem. Many apps can be moved to the SD card, and yes, the phone can be rooted if needed. The CPU can't tolerate much overclocking or underclocking; it can only go about 50 MHz in either direction before problems arise.I'm basing this review on a few days of use with a phone that I helped my dad choose. He wanted a model with a QWERTY keyboard, as too many touchscreen actions don't appeal to him. I have no plans to root his phone, though I may explain the process to him further if he is seriously interested in it. Otherwise he is happy with the way the phone works, so I don't foresee having to do this for him. If this were my next phone, yes, I would root it. There are a few ROMs available for the Slider, including the Mobster ROM. Most of the devs for these ROMs also don't recommend clocking the processor more or less than 800 MHz. The reason of this is of course the overclockers' classic enemy: heat buildup. Nothing's worse than a phone that turns to toast when you least expect it.All of that being said, it is possible to do a bit more than the usual with this phone. The keyboard can be useful if you run terminal emulators. Remember DOS and GUI-less UNIX terminals? Yeah, you know who you are! Type away all the Linux commands you can remember; most of them work here. :) Games? It does run quite a few well. I tested a 3d golf game, and a motorcycle 3d racer. Both ran fairly smoothly, with little slowdowns. YouTube video ran well, too. Web surfing is quite good for a lower end Android phone. You'll notice it when zooming full size pages to size.In short, this really is an improved version of the V. My only niggle is the lack of LED flash for the camera. At this point, that might break the deal for me, as I am fairly adept at touchscreen typing, after a year of using the V. If you simply need a QWERTY, this is still one of the better deals for a no contract phone in the USA, in mid 2012. The only other model I'd recommend is the Samsung Transform Ultra, which is on Boost Mobile.
title: LG Optimus Slider Prepaid Android Phone (Virgin Mobile)
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Cell Phones', 'No-Contract Cell Phones', 'Phones'], ['Sports & Outdoors', 'Fan Shop', 'Cell Phone Accessories']]

reviewText: Not sure why currently the shipment time is 5-8 weeks on Amazon, but I picked this up today from Best Buy (begrudgingly). The phone is basically the older Optimus V, which I currently have, with a faster processor (800Mhz vs 600Mhz - I could tell a big difference when using the operating system, it's much snappier now), more internal memory (512MB vs 256MB), a physical keyboard, and Anroid 2.3 (vs 2.2).  It's really a nice phone that you can tell is made well - the fit and finish is really nice.  The keyboard slider works well too - it's a very smooth action that just feels right.  My only complaint for this phone is that it has a fairly small screen of 3.2". It's just a little on the small side for browsing webpages and such.  Also, now that I think about it, I wish the camera had a flash for it. I do highly recommend this phone though if you're looking to switch to Virgin Mobile or to upgrade your Optimus V or Intercept.
title: LG Optimus Slider Prepaid Android Phone (Virgin Mobile)
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Cell Phones', 'No-Contract Cell Phones', 'Phones'], ['Sports & Outdoors', 'Fan Shop', 'Cell Phone Accessories']]

reviewText: I had an Evo 4G, but couldn't justify the high bill anymore, so I switched to Virgin Mobile and bought the Motorola Triumph.  I had a lot of trouble with the Triumph and was very disappointed in the reliability of the bluetooth, slowness of the GPS, poor quality of the speakerphone and the awful battery life.  I probably would have kept it if the bluetooth and GPS worked properly, but I'm glad I didn't because the LG Optimus Slider is great.  It's so good that I bought 2 (one for me and one for my wife).  I didn't think I'd like it for myself because I'm used to having a "high-end" phone, but as much as I like larger screen and faster processor on the Evo and the Triumph, the Optimus Slider's keyboard gives it the edge.  I didn't realize how much more I would be able to accomplish with a keyboard.  I'm typing text messages and emails out now that I never would have attempted with the on-screen keyboard and all of my messages are 100% accurate now.I also like the fact that there's an extended battery available for this phone here on Amazon, whereas the Motorola Triumph had no extended battery available.Finally, this phone just works.  GPS is available right away, bluetooth works reliably, the speakerphone is crystal clear, etc., etc.I highly recommend this phone.
title: LG Optimus Slider Prepaid Android Phone (Virgin Mobile)
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Cell Phones', 'No-Contract Cell Phones', 'Phones'], ['Sports & Outdoors', 'Fan Shop', 'Cell Phone Accessories']]

reviewText: Bought the LG Optimus Slider after my prior LG Rumor2 succumbed to water damage.This essentially is my first smartphone since switching from a basic feature phone.Overall experience with the Optimus Slider is mostly positive.Biggest positive for me:Since the Optimus Slider was released  before prices for the Beyond Talk plans increased I get to keep my old BT plan at its original price $25.Phone Experience:First time  with Android it was an easy transition got used it within the first day.Call Quality is quite good far better than LG Rumor2 I can hear people clearly.Speaker quality is very clear making my  MP3's bearable to hear even in noisy places.Battery life was abysmal the first few days. Before I got the phone I purchased 2x OEM BL44JN 1540MAH batteries of which its standard just encase. For the first few days with the OEM batteries I only got around 4 hours of use per battery at the time. Downloaded the Juice Defender app. each battery lasted me atleast 6-7 hours on normal use. Later bought an extended battery 3850mah(still skeptic on the mah 2 1/2x the power of the OEM) from Sporting Persistence. Battery life significantly increased to a days worth.Apps & Storage:Appspace is limited to around 150-160mb's. This forces me to think hard on which apps I want to keep. I remember reading that if I reach its limit the phone will not work properly as intended. So I limited myself to 10 downloadable apps leaving 40mb of extra space to be safe.Most of the apps run fine with no slowdown unless they happen to be emulators with games that require faster processing.Stuck with Gingerbread OS. That means I can't use apps meant for later versions. Also since the LG OS uses the ARM/6 CPU some apps that can be run on Gingerbread may not work if using this processor.Physical Keyboard:it's bigger than my Rumor2's physical keyboard pleasant to type with. However major downside for me is the backlight for  the keys. Unlike the Rumor2 the backlight doesn't stay lit. They automatically shut off a few seconds later unless pressed. I can't find the options if any to keep them lit. So my nightly texts are a bad experience in this regard.Camera:Max Picture size is 3.2mp while video is the old VGA 640X480 standard. Reminds me of the P&S; cameras prior 2005.Considering the small CCD it has its not best in lowlight at all. Picture quality is okay, and usable still not on par with my old Canon A310 from 2004. Physical camera shutter  button on the phone doesn't respond very well if wanting to take multiple photos. So the onscreen shutter button is best be used in that regard. Lacks a timer and flash. So essentially good enough only in well-lit conditions, but not with fast moving subjects. Video quality is the same with picture quality. Definitely not replacing my P&S; camera at all.Overall its a decent low-end handset for me as a texted.Didn't touch on every single detail, but eh  likely prior reviewers already done so.I do recommend getting a battery extender for this phone especially the fat variety that comes with a backplate for it. More battery life and a better grip atleast that is for me.March 2014 Update:Phone still functions flawlessly. Use it mostly as a WiFi hotspot for my android tablet.
title: LG Optimus Slider Prepaid Android Phone (Virgin Mobile)
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Cell Phones', 'No-Contract Cell Phones', 'Phones'], ['Sports & Outdoors', 'Fan Shop', 'Cell Phone Accessories']]

reviewText: Well, first off, this is my FIRST smartphone! YAY ME! Anyway, with the Virgin Mobile plan of $35 a month, you can't go wrong. You will get everything an iPhone user gets for almost a third of the price!!! Me being a college student, this is what I need and can afford.OK, so this phone is AMAZING!!! I LOVE IT!!! Alright, the battery will most likely be bad (I never tried it), but install an Extended Battery for it like I did (READ MY REVIEW ON IT FOR MORE INFO!!!).Anyway, the slide out keyboard is awesome and useful when typing for accuracy. Speaking of typing, I DO NOT like the swype keyboard, but it is optional so don't worry. Now the slide out keyboard does have one big downside..The stupid back button is next to the A button.. So if you slip and click the back button, you will lose your typed message.. Also the spacebar on the slide out keyboard is complete TRASH. You literally have to push directly in the center in order for it to pick up the keypress, you can't just press the edge of the spacebar.. Whatever, it's still faster then the touchscreen when aiming for accuracy.Now, the phone does not have that much internal memory. Now you're thinking to yourself, "It comes with an SD card, I don't need internal memory." WRONG! The stock apps suck up a lot more memory then you would think... Yes you can move some apps you download to the SD card, but most won't let you. So you won't be able to install a HUGE amount of apps. Plus remember that it will ask you to update apps (you can ignore it though) and that will use more internal memory for internal apps. Supposedly, you can ROOT and delete these stock apps, etc, but I'm not down for the risks and plus I haven't found a reliable up-to-date guide.As for the phone itself, I LOVE IT SO MUCH! I moved from a Pantech AT&T; Prepaid GoPhone to this phone and it is the best choice I've made in a long time! I have come across a couple Wi-Fi glitches, but maybe that's because I don't live in a cell service area..All in all, I recommend this phone to anyone wanting a GREAT smartphone with a top-line Operating System with a CHEAP monthly plan! Who needs the iPhone? All you're getting is debt! Android LG Optimus Slider FTW! :)
title: LG Optimus Slider Prepaid Android Phone (Virgin Mobile)
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Cell Phones', 'No-Contract Cell Phones', 'Phones'], ['Sports & Outdoors', 'Fan Shop', 'Cell Phone Accessories']]

reviewText: If possible I would give this phone 3  stars. The Optimus Slider is worlds faster and more reliable than my previous Virgin Mobile phone the Samsung Intercept but it still has some problems. It occasionally shuts down and the only way to restart is to remove the battery. Also, sometimes it will get really hot and blow through all your battery power in about an hour as if every app on the phone is running at once. To alleviate this problem I highly recommend the Advanced Task Killer by ReChild. Installing this app appears to have fixed that problem but I have to be dilligent about killing apps. Other than these two issues I've been happy with this phone especially coming from using one of the worst smartphones ever, the Intercept. However, if it breaks I probably won't buy it again. I'll be tempted to try out something else. Overall though I don't regret purchasing this phone and it was worth the low $180 price. However, if you don't need the sliding keyboard I would recommend going with the regular Optimus instead. That phone is lighter and smaller.
title: LG Optimus Slider Prepaid Android Phone (Virgin Mobile)
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Cell Phones', 'No-Contract Cell Phones', 'Phones'], ['Sports & Outdoors', 'Fan Shop', 'Cell Phone Accessories']]

reviewText: My wife and I both had Motorola Triumphs since they came out.  They were great, but my wife's would be a little quirky sometimes and she missed having a real keyboard.  I got her this one, and we love it.  The phone is snappy and works just as well or better than the far more expensive Triumph.  The screen is smaller, and on paper the processor is slower, but the phone works very well.  The keyboard is really nice.I couldn't be happier with this phone.  For now, I'm going to stick to my Triumph, because I like the larger screen, but this is so nice that I'm considering trading down as well.  I highly recommend this phone, especially since it has version 2.3 (Gingerbread) of Android, whereas a lot of the other VM phones (including the Triumph) are still on 2.2 (Froyo).Camera - Good.  3.2 MP count, but works well and takes good pictures.Reception - Good.  As good or better than the other VM phones I've had (Triumph/Intercept)Keyboard - Really nice.Screen - I like 4.3" better for my big hands and fingers, but 3.2" is adequate and it works well.  The touch is pretty good.Call quality - Great.  No better or worse than the Triumph.
title: LG Optimus Slider Prepaid Android Phone (Virgin Mobile)
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Cell Phones', 'No-Contract Cell Phones', 'Phones'], ['Sports & Outdoors', 'Fan Shop', 'Cell Phone Accessories']]

reviewText: I have had the LG800G Tracfone for about four months and have differing thoughts.  It is a good deal for a touch screen.  When it first came out, the price point was at $59.99.  Now (July 2012) it is at $49.99.  When I got mine through the Tracfone website, it was at $39.99.  Amazon is offering it for $32.99, which is a good deal.  The phone is easy to use and for a prepaid phone is a giant leap for the technology available.  Everything about the phone is fantastic except for texting.  There is no stylus provided with the phone and texting with your fingers is difficult.  There are different methods of texting input.  You can use the ABC method like the older analaog phones were.  You can use the QWERTY keyboard, which is difficult to do unless you use a pencil or other "stylus".  You can use the hand writing method.  I have been told that I print like a walking typewriter (Thanks to Mrs Foster my fourth grade teacher).  Even with this, I have to attempt up to five times to get a "T" not to register as a "J".  Be careful also about how you carry the phone when not in use.  The touch screen is very sensative and could engage when you don't want it to.  It is also annoying when getting a call.  As soon as you get the call, the screen goes into the lock mode and you have to hold the unlock icon if you need to press any keys for input, (Like when the prompt comes for you to enter 1 for this or enter 2 for that).  I do like the phone for daily use.  I just can't text with it.  Tracfones are relatively inexpensive so I have a second one that I use for texting.  My friends and family have gotten used to me having more than the one phone number.  Is it a Smart Phone?  It could be with the right apps.  Tracfone is pretty "propriotary" with their software and can only be downloaded through their sites so you are very limited on what you can do.  I am retired now and do not use my phone as I used to but like to have an upgrade from the "clamshell" type of phones.  If you can use a phone with touchscreen but again do not use the phone as your PC, this one is good.  If you use your phone for texting, this one could really slow you down.  Make sure you know what you are getting into when you get this one.  I might just retire this one into one of my desk drawers and go back to my LG500C.  After writng this review, I have done just what I said I might do.  Retired the LG800G into the top right drawer of my desk and used my LG500G I got from Amazon.  I hope this helped you make your decision of getting this phone or not.
title: LG 800G Prepaid Phone With Triple Minutes (Tracfone)
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Cell Phones', 'No-Contract Cell Phones', 'Phones']]

reviewText: I've had the LG800G now for 4 months and was pleased with it until last week. The lower row of keys on the virtual keyboard just quit (all of them).  I am a light user sending a few texts a week and even less calls per week.  I was happy with this phone overall as I did not have any of the issues that reviewers here pointed out (dropped calls, phone locking up, etc.).  I do not go online at all, so cannot say anything there.  I am very disappointed with this phone now as I can no longer send texts (unless I want to send the text as a very long string of letters, since I have no period, comma, space bar, etc.).  {Also, I have used a stylus to access different functions because I have long nails and touchscreens do not do well with them.} I gave this phone 2 stars because I think a phone should be made to last longer than 4 months; no wonder I got triple minutes for the life of the phone!  In reading the reviews here, I decided to try the Samsung S390G, and ordered it last week from Amazon. I sure hope that one will last me a lot longer than 4 months and with the actual QWERTY keyboard it has, I can do away with the virtual one and touchscreen altogether.  I've not had much luck with the touchscreen phones this past year at all. I hope those who have this phone have better luck than I did.
title: LG 800G Prepaid Phone With Triple Minutes (Tracfone)
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Cell Phones', 'No-Contract Cell Phones', 'Phones']]

reviewText: I purchased this phone for my husband who has been using a Motorola flip phone (Tracfone) for the past five years. The older phone was still working fine, but I needed a gift idea for Father's Day so I thought I'd 'upgrade' him to a touchscreen phone and the purchase of some extras for the phone was a good idea. I had looked at the more expensive Tracfone offerings:LG 840G Prepaid Phone With Triple Minutes (Tracfone)andLG Optimus Dynamic Android Prepaid Phone with Triple Minutes (Tracfone), but he's a cheap guy who doesn't text and makes about 2 short calls a month, so I thought this LG 800G would be a good choice.The flip phone also had triple minutes, so I was looking for that perk on this one. For those who have not experienced this before, you can add aTracfone 60 Minute Airtime Cardand get 180 minutes automatically with triple minute phones. This works with any size of additional minutes added - the minutes are tripled when added to this phone.ACTIVATION:Upon opening the sealed container we found the LG 800G, a wall charger, booklet and activation code (red card). After charging the phone; which took no time at all, I went to Tracfone dot com to port the flip phone's number to the new phone. **You CAN keep your old number when getting a new Tracfone.  If it sounds difficult call Tracfone and they'll walk you through it.I transferred the number by entering in the old phone number and the old phone and new phone's serial numbers - found in the PrePaid section of each phone. Tracfone indicated this process could take a couple hours, but up to 4 days in some cases. My deactivation of the old phone took about 1 hour, then I noted the phone number had been changed to the new phone, but the minutes had not transferred and neither phone was activated or could be used. Approximately 8 hours later, the new phone was activated by Tracfone, but it was missing minutes that should have been transferred.NOTE: Another great feature of Tracfone service is that the minutes rollover each month - you don't lose them! We had 1500 minutes on the old phone and only 1100 transferred.PROBLEM TRANSFERRING ALL THE MINUTES:I called Tracfone and after several 'hit this button to's', I got a real person, who was a tad hard for me to understand. Despite the language barrier, we did manage to get the lost 400 minutes transferred quickly and easily (while I was on the phone with the rep).I was happy and surprised to find out that the service activation is good for 1 year - not the expected 90 days before there is a need to add more minutes. For my husband, this means that he'll have a phone for free for 1 year, as he will never use 1500 minutes in 12 months.THE PHONE:I purchased a case, charging accessories, and screen protectors for under fifteen bucks on Amazon, and thus for twenty-five I have a fully functional, semi-smartphone with touchscreen input.  The 3x minutes and 1 year of service without a need to add minutes make this a super-sweet deal at under ten dollars.The phone itself is lightweight in its construction, and the touchscreen response is lacking by comparison to new, higher end phones, but hey, you're getting a lot for the price!The touchscreen requires calibration - you can do it in Settings on the phone, and when using the touchscreen you actually have to press versus just touching it lightly. Time will tell if that negatively affects performance of the phone.Web surfing on this phone can be done, but it's expensive and awkward. You can text with the phone (about thirty cents per text) , but it's not a phone that's the best for texting. It has a Qwerty touchscreen keyboard, as well as a number pad that can be used for data entry.There is no GPS on the phone, but you do have apps for email and other functions. You can buy games with your minutes, check the weather, input info into a calendar app, and use the phone as a MP3 player. (It has a 3.5mm headphone jack on the top of it, and a microSD slot on the side that will accept up to a 4GB card - available for about six dollars shipped.)Because it has Bluetooth, you can pair it with a hands-free headset or your car's Bluetooth. You can also pair it with a portable  Bluetooth speaker to enjoy your music from the phone - anywhere!There is a 2MP camera and you can take video with this phone. Obviously this is not the phone's strong-suit, but it does work and media can be saved to the internal memory or a microSD card (considered 'external' memory). You can also transfer photos from your old phone to the new phone with a cable transfer, or by transferring a microSD card between the two; putting photos from the old phone on the card and then putting the card into the new phone.The screen can be set as shown on Amazon, or to a darker, more attractive screen. You can use your photos as wallpaper on this phone.Call quality where I live is excellent. Sprint towers are used, and this phone can actually make and receive calls better than my Virgin Mobile powered iPhone 4S.My husband likes his new phone, but he says there is a learning curve for him. Thankfully there are also quite a few video tutorials on YouTube that are very helpful for figuring out the basic functionality of this phone.PROS:1. Inexpensive phone.2. 1 Year Service with Activation; instead of the usual 90 days, with additional service time added with more airtime added to the phone, which can be added at any time. (It means you don't have to worry about your phone being deactivated after 90 days if you haven't added additional minutes to keep it active.)3. You can text, call, take video, take photos, play games, surf the web, listen to music, and more!4. Easy to use; the icons make things clear.5. Triple Minute phone for the life of the phone.6. Bluetooth for connecting to hands free speakers and headsets.CONS:1. Feels cheap; lightweight construction, by comparison to higher end touchscreen phones.2. Touchscreen has to be depressed versus just touched, to operate.3. Using the Internet is expensive, and there is NO WIFI option to surf without using data.4. NO GPS or navigation options, other than to use the browser to use Google Maps or similar.TIP: If you want to check your Voicemail, call your phone via another phone, and when your Voicemail picks up, press * on the phone you are calling from and enter your passcode when prompted. This doesn't use your Tracfone's minutes when you're checking your Voicemail.Overall, this is a great buy when you consider you'll pay as much for two tall lattes. The price is what makes me give it 5 stars. My husband is happy with it, and I'm happy I was able to transfer minutes, and get a phone with a 1 year activation and triple minutes.I also purchased these accessories for the phone:3x LG 800G Premium Clear LCD Screen Protector Cover Guard Shield Protective Film Kit,Hard Case for LG 800G BLACK - SLCPC06-LG800GBKandLG 800G Combo Rapid Car Charger + Home Wall Charger + USB Data Charge Sync Cable for LG 800G.6/18/14: Successfully added a 4GB microSD card into this phone. You have to slide off the back of the phone, remove the battery, and put the card underneath the battery in a designated space. Mine didn't fit very well, but when the battery was placed and the cover was on, it all worked as expected.
title: LG 800G Prepaid Phone With Triple Minutes (Tracfone)

reviewText: Our elderly friend, close enough to be our great uncle, needed to have a phone but didn't really know how to go about it. Looking on Amazon, I located this LG phone which we know is a good brand from experience with it. This particular phone turned out to be a real bargain. Reduced in price, but not in quality. The icons are large, the font size in contacts and other features is plenty large. Everything about it seems to be perfect for an older person. The Triple Minutes feature was perfect, too. I had a $20 60-minute card from the local grocery and it made the amount become 180 minutes and it's nearly six months in time. Perfect for someone who really needs it mostly for an emergency or when he might be running late to something. Or, if he needs to call the doctor's office. Definitely recommend it for a friend. Has lots of features he may not use, but then, who knows, he may find it fun to play with the camera, which also does video. There's a voice recorder, an alarm, calculator, heck it's got lots of things! Don't remember the description saying, but it does come with a home charger and the instructions are really good, especially when compared to most other electronics you might by on sale. I say: Perfect. Perfect. Perfect.
title: LG 800G Prepaid Phone With Triple Minutes (Tracfone)

reviewText: The LG800G is the best phone Tracfone has now with most of the features people would like in their phone. For me it's as my second phone as I also have a hard line, I use this phone when out and about. It does take good pictures but the screen is a bit too small to use for the internet option, though it can be done. I suggest that you get the extra storage chip and cord so you can connect it to your Pc and a screen protector (3 to a pack) to keep it from being scratched, all these can be purchased together group for a few $ here on Amazon and less than on ebay..This is the second TracFone I have had the other was an old Motorola flip phone so after 2+ year of use the battery went bad so rather than buying another battery I sprang for a new phone (my kids told me I had been working with vintage technology) I am extremely satified with this phone.  There are features which I haven't explored yet----BUT THE PRICE IS RIGHT and NO CONTRACT, buy only the airtime you need. With this phone came triple minutes for the life of the PHONE which means when you buy 100 minutes what actually receive is 300 minutes of air time, I buy minutes a year at a time. It also works with the bluetooth feature in my car--hands free thru the radio. There is also other special aps like ITunes which you can purchase if you think you need them in exchange for your air time minutes as these minutes have a dollar value...PS- the phone still works even after my dog chewed the cornor off of it. LESSON LEARNED- DON'T LET YOUR DOG USE YOUR PHONE THEY JUST DON'T KNOW HOW TO TAKE CARE OF THEM.Dick Tracy

reviewText: Got it from HSN in December. Returned it because of Tracphone's outrageous cost per minute. If you get the maximum minutes bundle with the triple minutes plan, it's still like 10-11 cents a min. Buy the smallest bundle and it's more like 33 cents a min. So at best you pay $6/hr to gab?! At worst, $19.80/hour! Remember the stores charge tax on these cards as do the company when you refill from them.Signal was great in rural Ohio, clear, best I have had of 8 phones. Sorry to send it back, as it was comfortable, not too big or heavy, and battery was good. It didn't run apps for me - and I wasn't into using much internet as it's too little to see. Phone has a sim card, so can't switch to Virgin network, or I'd have kept it.Straight Talk and Tracphone share customer service - generally poorly comprehending Indian reps who create very long, frustrating calls if you deviate from scripted talk. The voice menu lets you choose which phone service you are calling about. However, Tracphone is better than Straight Talk's service, which is why I quit ST. Weigh your cost-to-frustration benefit before buying.
title: LG 800G Prepaid Phone With Triple Minutes (Tracfone)
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Cell Phones', 'No-Contract Cell Phones', 'Phones']]

reviewText: We purchased this phone at a chain store for $49.99.  We've always  owned cheap pay as you go phones, because the value is fantastic and we hate getting ourselves into pricey contracts.  This phone is smart in looks only.  The features are awful, the touch screen finicky...it's basically a toy phone meant to "look" like a fancier one.  My husband has had his for about 6 months and it just kept getting worse.  We just replaced it with a $65 Optimus Elite and what a world of difference.  Seriously...unless you're getting this for a child, never use your phone, and rarely text I cannot recommend it.  If you have never ever owned any other touch screen device, you might think this is pretty nifty. We have always gone with low end pay as you go's, but we would have preferred one of the non touch screen ones over this.  The pros are that it is super cheap (especially on amazon) and tracfone is fairly reliable and a very inexpensive service.  The cons are that the phone is just doesn't work well after a couple of months, and the touch screen on my 5 year old daughters leapfrog toys are better made and less finicky. You also have to push really hard for the icons to access. Reminds me of our fussy touch screen fax machine at work. Accessing the web for anything is worse than the caveman days of dial up modems and AOL service.  Given the price and always phenomenal tracfone service rates, this would be a good "first phone" for a younger child or a decent emergency phone to throw in your glove box. I'm surprised by all the great reviews for this one...we're not fussy people and this phone didn't even meet our extraordinarily low expectations for it.
title: LG 800G Prepaid Phone With Triple Minutes (Tracfone)
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Cell Phones', 'No-Contract Cell Phones', 'Phones']]

reviewText: That is true but sometimes you get a bargain. This phone does everything I need it to do and than some. I like it, I rcommend it, and Tracphone is always a good deal.

reviewText: My family has used Tracfone for years and this is the 7th phone we've bought.  This was a replacement for my old phone which after 5 years finally died.  This was my FIRST Tracfone bought somewhere other than the Tracfone website and I will probably be doing this in this in the future as it seems to be the cheaper option.I was able to transfer my old phone number and minutes with ease through the website and the process was pretty painless.The phone itself is the nicest one by far we've ever gotten.  Camera, MP3 player, games, web access, memo pad, calendar, alarms, touch screen... it seems to have everything I'd need and mostly stuff I'll probably never use but I'm still annoyed that it touts having the MP3 player but you have to buy the SD card and cord separately for it to be of use.  I have purchased those but they have not yet arrived so I can't say if that feature is any good or not.The thing I like best about this phone was that adding contacts was so much easier with the "handwriting" option rather than using the keypad.  I could use my finger and I got some measure of accuracy but using a toothpick I was able to just write in all my contact names and numbers in no time at all.  It was just awesome.  I imagine there has got to be a stylus somewhere for sale for this phone you can buy separately.  I'll probably stick to my toothpick which is free and handy.The phone menu is a vastly different set up than anything I had previously but it didn't take too long to get used to and now I feel pretty comfortable with it.  Tracfones are always very simple to use, and that is somewhat appealing to me, I don't have to spend hours to familiarize myself with them.  They get the job done efficiently and cheaply.  This phone though looks more complicated than it is.  Fool your friends into thinking you have an expensive cell plan!  Then laugh as you have loads more money at the end of the month!EDIT - I have since began using the MP3 feature and I love it.  It works so well and I have since stopped using my old MP3 player even though the sound quality on it was better.  This is just so much more convenient because it is also my phone.I have also figured out how to disable the "lock screen" that comes up automatically on the phone.  That was so annoying to me.  So now my phone is just the way I like it.EDIT - I have also discovered you can convert your videos to GP3 format and load them on this phone and play videos.  This is a lifesaver for me because I don't like my <2 year old son to play with my more expensive Sony media player or my Galaxy Tablets, so I can just give him my inexpensive phone and load a video and he's happy.  I am seriously considering just buying another phone just for him for the purposes of a cheap video player only...  Not sure if you can use the phone for video if you don't buy service time though - I'll have to investigate further.
title: LG 800G Prepaid Phone With Triple Minutes (Tracfone)
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Cell Phones', 'No-Contract Cell Phones', 'Phones']]

reviewText: I have been using this LG phone for several months and find it difficult, at best to manage competently.  Although it is the only touch-type phone that TracPhone  offers I believe that it needs a great deal more R and D.  Most of the time it is ultra-sensitive and makes calls as I am attempting to scroll through contacts.  The off-on switch is very small and difficult to manage, unless the phone is in your face.  There is more but, believe me - LG has not created a great touch phone.  As a "wanna-be android" it just doesn't accomplish the task.  I am going back to a simpler design.

reviewText: Pros:1.It's cheapest way I could find to have cell phone that does not look like it's from stone age)))You can get 90 days of service for $19.99 and 60 minutes tripled.2.You can make decent pictures with it,but only if you have good light.There is no flash and no zoom.3.You can use it as MP3 player.4.Reception is good,but I am in a major metro area so that may not be true for everyone.Cons:1.These phones are not very smart)))For some reason it does not turn off screen lock even if I change settings to say never lock the screen.It also locks up during every call,so if you are asked to dial something during a call you have to press and hold every time and still it does not go straight to dial pad mode-very frustrating.2.There is a good chance you might get a glitchy phone.I had to return first one because it would just go dead even when fully charged, for no reason.The only way to turn it on again was to take out and reinsert battery.My first phone would also be unusable while charging.However I had no problems returning it free of charge for a full refund.3.Every time I call voicemail it keeps going on and on about new voicemail features for about a minute, it's eating up my minutes and there is no option to skip it.4.I have to pay for incoming calls and text messages, it is same rate as outgoing.Even if you only pick up to say a few quick words,for example "it's a wrong number" you get charged a full minute.

reviewText: This is like the fourth one I've purchased. They work fine, its just my son keeps sending them thru the wash in his pants pocket. Yep three phones in one year.  I like the minute increments. He never makes phone calls anyway. Just texts. But it serves his emergency needs and my peace of mind. I'm afraid if I spent $300 on a phone and it was left in the wash, I'd be really mad. This way I can continue providing reliable bare bones phone support without crying over the price or worrying about him managing downloads or minutes. He's really picky over how he spends his minutes.  And believe it or not, I have been able to get any remaining minutes on the washed out unusable ones, transferred over to the new phone. When he can keep this alive for more than a year without incident, then we'll talk about upgrading.

reviewText: For the price of this phone it's great you can't go wrong. I bought this for my husband and he just loves it. it's all touch screen, it has 3 buttons on the bottom: call, back button,(an arrow  curving back to the left) end. it has a button on the top which is the off & on button when you push and hold it. it will shut off or turn on. It's easy to put your contact in. Does have internet, does take memory card. You can have it to lock or not to lock at all. I put it on do not lock but it does lock and it's easy to unlock all you have to do is hold the lock and it will unlock. There is away to get around the lock. If you push the top button it will take you to your home screen with out being locked. Also if you are getting a call you can hit send without pushing the lock to unlock the phone also works when you end the call, just push end. You have different ringtones which are great there are some nice ones on there. Also has picture id as well as caller id & ring tone. I have this phone set to where it will show who is calling with their name & picture. When you put their contact info in the phone hit edit and add a photo also make sure you click the ringtone and give them a ringtone or it will not have a ringtone and will not ring. You can set it to not answer calls if it's blocked, easy to text on as well. Getting Triple minute is a great bonus with this phone can't go wrong for the price.
title: LG 800G Prepaid Phone With Triple Minutes (Tracfone)

reviewText: The texting is a bit awkward for me, not being a 14 yr. old girl but a 71 yr. old man.  You need to change screens several times to complete a text. However, all the setup and added minutes went without a hitch.  I just ordered one for my wife to replace her Lg500.I emailed Tracfone requesting speaker phone use info. and have not heard from them, as of Dec. 26., but their online tutorial, found by my own initiative did work for me. Don't count on Tracfone help via email.  The user booklet wasn't clear.After using the LG800G a couple weeks I found the battery goes down way faster than advertised. (4 hr talk, and 8 day standby) It has to be discharged fully and recharged a couple time and should be OK. Sending photos deducts 1 full minute.  Most of the photos have NOT actually gotten thru, but the time was deducted.  Texts deduct 20 seconds, though they only take about 2-3 seconds to send.HOWEVER, the one I ordered for my wife and today tried to transfer her current LG500 Tracfone # and minutes, but it only transferred the minutes and gave a new number! Numerous tries say they cannot transfer an inactive # to a new phone....they deactivated the old number when they gave the new one.  As before good luck trying any customer service. It's all automated when you call, with no option for a live person. The phone is good; the customer service is not.

reviewText: I bought the LG 800g to replace an old flip phone that I had for years, which was also a Tracfone. I wanted a phone that could access the internet and one that would support some apps but I didn't want a contract and pay $50 - $100 a month and I didn't want to pay hundreds of dollars for a phone either. This phone is perfect for me. I can access the internet and check my email, do some surfing and even Ebay. You can Bookmark the mobile versions of many websites. I also downloaded the Opera Mini browser for free and it works great. For under $40 dollars, you get more then your money's worth. With internet access, texting (it even has hand writing recognition), camera, music and of course voice calls, you can't go wrong with this phone. Internet connection speed has been good for me too. Although at times it hangs,  most of the time it's a good connection. And you can add more storage by getting a SDHC Flash Memory Card. Calls are very clear too. This is a full feature phone. It may not be an android but there are many free Java apps out there. I downloaded for free, a ton of ringtones, wallpapers and games and installed Google Maps, which works great. I also downloaded a mobile spreadsheet app. And I synced my Bluetooth headset. File transfer between PC and phone is a breeze. Just be sure to get the USB cable. I'm more then pleased with this phone and I'm still discovering all that it can do. I would recommend it to anybody who would like a smart phone but doesn't want to spend the money. Also, with this phone you get triple minutes for life, which is a great deal. I average about $10 a month on mine, so I feel that I have a great deal and get a lot for that 10 bucks. Transferring over my Tracfone phone number and minutes was smooth too. It took about 20 minutes on the phone and all worked out great. And the seller Shopcelldeals is great too. I got my phone in 2 days.
title: LG 800G Prepaid Phone With Triple Minutes (Tracfone)
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Cell Phones', 'No-Contract Cell Phones', 'Phones']]

reviewText: I was amazed at all of the features crammed into this phone.  No, it isn't a smart phone, but it has many of the features found on phones that cost much more. It is pleasing to look at, compact, performs well.  The interface is easy to use once you learn how to use it.  The instructions included fail to provide everything that you need to know about phone operation and it will probably be necessary to download an LG owners manual or go to the Tracfone site to see an explanation of how all of it's features and settings work. But other than that, I am still amazed at how well this phone works. If you want the look and most of the features of a smart phone at a fraction of the price, this phone will not disappoint. reviewText: ~ For just making mobile calls anywhere in the USA to anywhere in the world, this LG Trac-Fone Phone is an excellent "pay as you go" option with wide US coverage ~The majority of the USA is not using this phone so you won't find all the trendy and numerous Apps & Games, it doesn't talk back to you, it does not have GPS, and celebrities won't be seen using it but it is comparable in quality & basic offerings to most phones costing much, much more. Plus the batteries are not soldered in like some phones requiring you to send your phone away and pay someone else to replace it. It also has a memory slot inside, unlike others, to add more memory options to your phone. It includes many features. Some of my favorites: I can either buy games directly off phone or buy a cheap memory card and load it with java games & apps off the internet or my PC; Customizable Menus; Texting/E-mailing to phones or computer users; I can insert my stand-alone camera's vacation photos into it and show them anywhere. If someone wants a copy, I can just send it as an attachment to their cell phone# or e-mail address.  Besides the deeply discounted and dependable cell service, my favorite feature is the MP3 player and Music Software Suite. Not only can the phone display an album Cover (if included in song file) it has a graphic equalizer to adjust Bass, Treble Etc. It scrolls at the touch of a finger to find the right song or you can use the advanced search option to find a specific tune. You can even slide the song (or video) to any position with your finger. You can adjust the volume with a touch-slide or press side buttons on phone. The headphone port accepts all standard mini-phono jacks so you do not need to special order them.It's appearance is streamlined & quite similar to many trending phones and more so if a 'skin' is used; it does not scream 'Prepaid'. There are many hits and some misses but for the price you can not go wrong. The Phone is customizable; I can buy various skins, guards, protective screen films, tripods, headphones, chargers etc. from different brands, buy or load different wallpapers & ringtones from my PC and I can load all of my favorite music on a memory card and use it just as an iPod but for 90% less. Even if I no longer keep it activated it can be used or shared & recycled as a stand alone LQ Video Camera, MP3 Player, Picture Camera, Calculator, Tip Formulator, Digital Photo Scrapbook Screen, Night-Time Key-Hole Finder, Phone Book, Mini-Game Console, & Voice Recorder.Some people insult these phones merely for NOT being a Premiere model but a premium price is not being paid, so don't expect it!?Top notch Phones & Plans combined can cost hundred$ or thou$ands a year and require a two year Legal Financial Contract and a credit check! If you are an infrequent user and don't need to be a trend-copier but still want a Dependable, Durable, Economical yet Multi-Functional Phone with _Some_ options, this Trac-Fone Model is for you. [I suggest the yearly card for the very best rates- first year average about 35c a day (127yr) and includes over 20 hours of talk time using the triple minutes 27c 2nd year]*  Note: Is not compatible with the majority of Apps & Services advertised towards the costly models.**  Initial setup may require patience & time from customer service but it appears most phones areset-up instantly -> to three days max. Rarely, a week if a new sim card is given.***  Just a few setting are somewhat hidden and not under the settings tab. May take a moment to find.****  Siri is not included to talk to you and tell you bad jokes.
title: LG 800G Prepaid Phone With Triple Minutes (Tracfone)

reviewText: I recently got this LG800g Tracfone to replace an older LG225 flip phone, primarily because I wanted a cookie type phone that could also serve as an mp3 player. I purchased a data cable, 4 gb micro disk (the max for this particular phone), and silicone gel case from Amazon, so for under $70 I have everything I need to make this phone function for all my needs. When connected to a docking station, the sound is awesome--and welcome--since our local radio station decided Central California residents are no longer interested in classical music. Transferring my number and minutes over to the new phone was easy with Tracfone's customer service.As for transferring music onto your Tracfone, just be sure you connect to "Mass Storage" so the device icon shows up in "My Computer". Then it's a snap to cut and paste or copy/paste from one drive to another.If you are new to the LG800g, Google tutorials for an impressive list of tasks. I did this to create playlists for my phone so I can separate the classics from the Celtic and so forth.With the triple minutes for life option, I will never run out of minutes. Neat!
title: LG 800G Prepaid Phone With Triple Minutes (Tracfone)
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Cell Phones', 'No-Contract Cell Phones', 'Phones']]

reviewText: I bought this phone for my husband, who does not use phones often enough to remember how to use them. This LG has been quite a success! It is much easier for him to use than the two clam shells he tried (both were Tracfone), because of the icons. I set up the phone and contact list for him (very easy), and he has not had any trouble placing or answering calls. The phone is light and slim enough for him to put in a pocket. It is fairly slick, so I bought a gel case for it on Amazon.
title: LG 800G Prepaid Phone With Triple Minutes (Tracfone)
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Cell Phones', 'No-Contract Cell Phones', 'Phones']]

reviewText: Look it's a great phone.  I replaced my old Motorola flip phone with it and they extended my year end agreement by 90 days.  I also got lifetime triple minutes.  All for $37!!!  It cost me $4 from Amazon.com to get the 4gb micro card.  I had bought the 8gb micro card it said it would take and nothing would make it work.  I called Tracfone and learned it will ONLY take 4gb. Now it works perfectly.  One must go into photo camera and page 2 to activate/change over to the additional memory card.  SIMPLE.  As a phone it is excellent.  People can actually hear me.  I can hear them.  The camera is great 2mb will store like 1100 pictures on the extra card or alot of music.  There are crazy features like internet access I rarely use for other than weather and international calling and texting is crazy cheap.  In SHORT I love this phone.  I am 65 and probably will never have to buy another cell phone.  Just cancelled my AT&T land line long distance as this is cheaper by far.  Thanks Tracfone.
title: LG 800G Prepaid Phone With Triple Minutes (Tracfone)
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Cell Phones', 'No-Contract Cell Phones', 'Phones']]

reviewText: I have been a Net10 customer for the past five years and have had good service. If you need to buy minutes or basic needs on their web page you will be OK, BUT if you need to talk to someone for help you may be in for a real experience. My wife and I have had Net10 phones for five years and have been happy. I decided to purchase a new phone for my wife that would be easier to text from so I purchased the LG-800G. It came in two days and looks like it would do a nice job for us. My wife does not use her phone much so her minutes pile up. I use my phone much more so I don't have many minutes but lots of service days.I called and spoke to a Net10 Service Rep. and asked if they could transfer the 2200 minutes from My wife's phone to my phone. The Rep. said "Sure". She had me enter data on my wife's phone to take the minutes off her phone and move them to my phone. Well, she got the minutes off of her phone but they never showed up on my phone. I have been on the phone for several hours the past three days with no success. I have been given Ticket Numbers for special help. These have no meaning as the next person I talk to has no idea why I am calling and I have to explain why I am calling each time. The reps. spend most of your time updating their logging system and not providing any meaningful help to the customer.My last call was to a specialist who spent his time updating his records and then told me he was replacing my phone and I would have to return my phone which is out of warranty. He had no idea if that would fix my problem. At that point, I had had enough and told him to keep the phone and I would look for a new carrier. I have read other reviews from people with similar experiences. NOW I know what they are talking about. Net10/Tracphone has good products but their customer support is about as bad as it gets. I am seventy one years old and have never experienced customer service this bad.
title: LG 800G Prepaid Phone With Triple Minutes (Tracfone)
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Cell Phones', 'No-Contract Cell Phones', 'Phones']]

reviewText: I order this phone on Monday 19,2012 and recieved on Wenseday 21,2012. That was fast great service. I've been looking for a touchscreen phone at a reasonable price and found one finally. Love the phone it works well..Thanks:)
title: LG 800G Prepaid Phone With Triple Minutes (Tracfone)
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Cell Phones', 'No-Contract Cell Phones', 'Phones']]

reviewText: I recently bought this LG 800G "smart" phone to replace another LG (500) with the teeny-tiny keypad for texting.  Using that phone was a nightmare, seeing how my one finger would routinely push down 2-3 keys at the same time.  Using the new LG 800G is such a nice upgrade from that mini keyboard- love that handwriting recognition feature!  The LG 800 has a great sounding MP3 player (with equalizer and CD cover art), a really good quality camera with instagram-esque filters you can add to your photos, and a very handy touch screen that makes it extremely user friendly.I initially had a problem switching phones - the phone number tranfered okay, but the minutes I had on my old phone (1988) showed up as 0 on my new phone.  I kept getting the "activation required" message as well.  After calling Tracfone 2 times, they had my new LG 800G up and running - and as you can guess, I love it!  If you're looking for a cheap upgrade from a basic Tracfone, this is the one to get.  No- it isn't an iPhone or even one of the many Samsung droid smart phones, but for $30 and $100 for 400 minutes per year (did I mention this phone has 3x minutes!) it'll leave your hard earned dollars in your wallet to be spent on other more important things.  Do iPhone users really spend $600+ a year for data plans + $200 for the phone?  My LG 800g is good enough for what I use it for (actually calling people, texting, and light internet use).
title: LG 800G Prepaid Phone With Triple Minutes (Tracfone)
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Cell Phones', 'No-Contract Cell Phones', 'Phones']]

reviewText: I have a few issues with this bluetooth. First, the app that they have designed to work with this bluetooth won't work unless you have media and audio options being used with your phone which means that if you are using the A2DP part of the bluetooth with a second device, you cannot hear text messages through your bluetooth. This works with other talk-to-text apps. Secondly, I left my iPod connected to my bluetooth in my house on the first floor and I stepped outside to get something from my car approximately 10 feet away and the music started stuttering and cut out all together at one point. Not good AT ALL! Lastly, the earpiece on the bluetooth IS uncomfortable; but, just as another customer recommended, buying some smaller and more comfortable earbuds REALLY did the trick. I bought another bluetooth to replace this one, hopefully, so I'll probably return it. Another thing, a question I had before I purchased this bluetooth was "Can it connect to two devices at one time?" The answer is absolutely. I have it connected to my phone and my iPod touch as I type. Sound quality is excellent. People I talked to did not know I was on a bluetooth.  One more thing I forgot about that I REALLY didn't like.  Usually my bluetooth headsets that connect to two devices will pause my music while I take a call then resume my music after the call has ended.  My music just kept playing through the call which means I will need to physically stop my music from playing while I'm on the phone.  This is VERY inconvenient when you are working and not near your musical device.
title: New LG HBM260 Bluetooth Wireless Headset Text-To-Speach & HD Music Streaming (Bulk Packaging)
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Headsets', 'Bluetooth Headsets']]

reviewText: This is for LG HBM260 Bluetooth wireless headset with text to speach and HD music. This product is great! Easy to pair, set up and use. Battery life is extremely long....I haven't charged it yet. Talk time is great, haven't run out of battery when using it. The text to speech works fantastic. With a tap on the front you pick up your calls. Use two taps and it will dial the last number you spoke with. When turning on it automatically tells you the battery life "Connected...x amount of battery remaining."Talk range is easily 30 feet or so, I went out onto my front porch and had an hour and a half conversation before I realized that I had left my cell in the house! Noise reduction is great, I haven't had any complaints from callers. My husband also has one and I can not tell if he is on a blue tooth or straight cell. There is no echo and the call is crisp.The only reason that I give it 4 stars is that it fits rather large in my ear and does hurt. I have to remove it constantly and never can forget that I have it on. I called LG and asked if there is a smaller ear-bud that I could order, unfortunately, there isn't one. I love it and don't want to change, but being a woman I believe I have a smaller ear than a man and this appears to be geared towards men. The one I purchased for my husband works great and he loves it and has no complaints.
title: New LG HBM260 Bluetooth Wireless Headset Text-To-Speach & HD Music Streaming (Bulk Packaging)
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Headsets', 'Bluetooth Headsets']]

reviewText: I really like the features and the call quality of this headset. When I've asked people I'm talking to they cannot tell that I'm using a headset, and my end is always nice and clear. I like that it tells you how much charge is left in the battery when you turn it on, and that it uses the same micro-usb connector as my phone does, so I can pretty much charge it anywhere. Battery life is really good too. I've had it for about a month and have only had to charge it once... granted, I don't live on my phone and really only use it when I'm in the car, but that's still good battery life. It also reads text messages and streams music from my phone, that's pretty neat too.On the down side, the rubber ear piece that is included, and there's only one, hurt my ears. Luckily it takes a standard size earpiece and I was able to get an assortment of different sizes for 99 cents from a different vendor. Now I don't even need the ear hook.

reviewText: Bought this for my wife who loves to talk on the phone so she seemed to be using it all the time. I couldn't tell when she was or wasn't using while talking to me so clearly call quality was good. She kept it constantly charged so I can't attest to battery life. I was a bit surprised by the packaging though,  it literally comes in a clear plastic bag,  no box, or protective packaging save for the shipping envelope.  I guess this helps with the price which was super cheap so no complaints from me. It was simple enough to operate that my wife could master it in a day without bugging me for help (she's horrible with anything electronic) so overall we're both pretty happy with this product.

reviewText: I had purchased the HBS-700 and when one of the ear buds stopped working after about 1 year, I promptly set out to purchase the HBS-730. Great quality sound for talking as well as listening to music. I never have to worry about "where did I put my bluetooth?" because it stays comfortably around my neck. I forget it is even on my neck because it is so light.I love the pause, rewind, FF, features, especially when I'm working out. I don't have to mess with my cell phone, I just push a button the the my HBS-730 headset. And I love how easy it is to pair with my devices. Only improvement I seek is to make the little plastic rings that hold the ear bud cords more sturdy. On both the HBS-700 and the HBS-730, the little plastic rings broke, and I was not rough with them. But I still rate this headset 5 stars! I've had many bluetooths over the years, and by far this is the best.
