reviewText: Pros: All the features on this headset are excellent. It has user friendly controls, sounds good, and has a long battery life. The vibration feature and voice verification on connection status are helpful for hands-free demanding moments.Con: It only lasted 5 months of daily use before one of the wired ear phone connections failed. Earbud headset wires typically are the first thing to fail on headsets I use, because I mostly wear them while I'm active outdoors and indoors. I'm careful not to strain the fragile wires, but they occasionally get over-strained and, over time, they structurally fail. In this case, the overstrained region occurs where the headset wires insert into the plastic body. As much as I like these, I think I'm going to use stereo bluetooth headsets that permit plugging in ones own set of earphones/buds with a standard headphone jack, because it ends up costing me less overtime if I just have to replace the wired earphone part of the headset device. If LG, or other manufactures, offered better structurally reinforced earbud wires for the integrated headset products, I might go back to buying that design.

reviewText: I bought this after I got irritated with my Motorola S10-HD for its heavy pulling nature on my ears. I found two models of LG (HBS 700 and HBS 730) and I opted for this.  I liked the below features:1. Pretty light weight, you won't feel as if you were wearing it over the neck. Fits well around your neck under the collar or over the T-shirt.2. Sound clarity is just awesome. May be because of the aptX codec, the bass sound is just perfect.3. Long battery life.4. Magnetic holders for the ear-phone plugs.5. Multi-device connection. Note: all the controls work with the primary device only, only incoming audio from secondary device. Very handy if you have a phone and tablet to manage through.6. Even if you have the earphone in your ears for long time, you would NOT feel like pulling due to their lightweight.7. The range is good. It works without breaking for up to 20 feet. After that you would hear crackling noise and then disconnected. I would not worry about the range.8. Very handy while you drive. The controls for phone and audio playback work perfect.I tried it while jogging but felt like it was going to slip but never fell down. I did not try running faster and so do not know if it would fall down while doing so.I would recommend for anyone who is looking for a lightweight bluetooth headset with a very nice audio output.
title: LG Electronics Tone+ HBS-730 Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Headsets', 'Bluetooth Headsets'], ['Electronics', 'Accessories & Supplies', 'Audio & Video Accessories']]

reviewText: This well-designed product has been a dream come true. I like to listen to music or audiobooks at the gym and around the house. Wired headphones get in the way. When not in use, it seems the headphone wires go out of their way to get tangled. Daily frustration to untangle. Not anymore. For not much more than a medium-priced pair of earbuds, you get wireless earbuds of comparable sound qualify. Solid bass, decently dynamic sound. Range is fine with your device in your pocket or within 8-10 feet. Within that short range, its connection is reliable. Good enough for me. This device was charged out of  the box, paired with my phone immediately, and the battery life is better than I thought it would be. You can use these several hours a day for several days before a recharge is needed. Again, good enough for me. Very comfortable to wear even when lying down. At the gym, it does bounce around while running but I simply tucked it underneath my shirt collar to keep it from bouncing. The magnetic tips to hold the earbuds work well. This is a thoughfully designed unit. Highly recommended.
title: LG Electronics Tone+ HBS-730 Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Headsets', 'Bluetooth Headsets'], ['Electronics', 'Accessories & Supplies', 'Audio & Video Accessories']]

reviewText: First, I have to admit, I don't like using this in my pick-up, so I kept my other bluetooth headset for everyday use. As far as using it for a stereo headset, this thing rocks. I've read other reviews talking about the usual bluetooth issues - comes unpaired, can't get more than six inches from the phone, etc. I don't have those problems, and I have to think that those who do must have an inferior phone - maybe I'm wrong, but I have NEVER had those kind of issues, with any BT device. My current phone is a Galaxy Note 2. I have a 2200 sq. ft. home and I can set my phone down anywhere in it and go anywhere else in the house and still hear my music. The only place I use a BT headset for talking on the phone is in the truck. I don't care for the Tone+ in that application, simply because it blocks out most of the outside noise - just a preference thing, I guess. It does work great for phone calls and texting, I just don't use it that way, for reasons stated. The bottom line, in my world anyway, if headphone cords annoy you, this is a great purchase.

reviewText: I've had the original Tone headphones (HBS-700) on my Wish List for some time and finally received them for Christmas this year. Let me tell you something: I had NO idea what I was missing! If I'd realized how great these headsets were, I would have purchased them for myself a long time ago.In the few days I have had them, I've easily used them for several multi-hour sessions (watching movies at night on my Tablet or music on my phone) with NO discomfort. In fact, I find it difficult to find earbuds small enough to comfortably fit my ears for more than a half an hour, but the default installed earbuds fit perfectly! (There are two additional, larger sets included).On top of that, at night I put on a movie or show on Netflix to fall asleep to, but wear headphones so as to not wake my spouse. Prior to receiving these, my favorite set have been a wired set of Vizio, which, if I rolled to my side, would become uncomfortable in the ear pressed into my pillow, and are often yanked out as the wire would get tangled up as I rolled around in my sleep.These have such a low profile in the ear that there is no pressure or discomfort when laying on my side. Even more impressive is that they remain in place even after moving around in my sleep. I just remove them on my first arousal after falling asleep. Even after using them the night before, I can use them the following day for several hours before recharging them for the next night.Ultimately, after only a few days, I purchased this model, the Tone+ (HBS-730), but kept the HBS-700 model for my spouse. The Tone+ solves my only gripe with the standard model: the lack of a mute; a necessary feature for professional conference calls. The Tone+ also add several improvements including a vibration alert for incoming calls and best of all, the ability for the Tone+ to be actively paired with 2 devices simultaneously (be it 2 phones or a phone and a tablet, for example).I am simply stunned by the quality and features available for the Tone+ given the price. It's hard to find a quality set of wired headsets, or a single-ear headset for this price.In short, I am very impressed and am very happy with this product that I use daily.PROs:+Extremely comfortable.+Very good sound quality for the average user.+Impressive battery life.+Simultaneous active pairing to 2 devices+OUTSTANDING VALUE (hard to beat the price/quality even compared to a quality wired headset)NEUTRAL:=Noise-blocking earbuds. Great for focusing on a conversation or your media. However, less useful for use with a Playstation and dangerous if used while driving (I have a standard headset for these situations).=The thin wire connecting the earbuds to the base may not be as durable long-term as some heavier-duty wired earbuds. However, there is almost never any tension on the earbud wires. But, given that I use them to sleep, I've purchased a 3-year replacement plan through Squaretrade for $10 (30% off) that even covers wear and tear.=SMS Text Reader app was not personally tested, but Android Play Store reviews seem to indicate that the required app is hit or miss based on your specific device.CONs:-Sound quality may not stack up for a true audiophile.-The Bluetooth connection can be tempermental. Even the human body, if place between the device and the headset (such as putting your phone in a back pocket) has the potential to interfere with the signal. This is personally a rare problem, but a surprising one when it occurs.

reviewText: Pros:The microphone quality on the Tone+ HBS-730 is much much better when compared to the previous model. The stereo audio quality is also noticeably better. The additional features are well worth the price of the upgrade. I personally appreciate the ability to connect to two Bluetooth devices at once allowing me to use both my laptop and cellphone in cafes and airport lounges. Carefully following the written directions I paired the Tone+ first with my MBP then manually paired it with my Android cellphone, this sequence makes the cell my primary device and my laptop my secondary. When a call comes in I can press the MBP mute button and the cellphone takes over the audio on the device.Cons:The Tone+ has a severely limited range when compared to its predecessor. When wearing winter clothing, if I put the phone in my rear jeans pocket the cell phone will disconnect from the Tone+. While placing the device in my front right jeans pocket, if I turn my body to the left and look up (placing my body between the left call button on the Tone+ and the cell phone's "chin" region) I will disconnect the cellphone and the Tone+. With the device in my front-right pocket, if my wife gives me a hug, I will disconnect the device. I suspect larger people might have more of a problem as I can get the device to disconnect by wrapping my hand around the right part of my cellphone. That indicates the signal doesn't do well with transmitting through the body... and the meatier you are... the more problems you may have. To work around this disconnect problem I keep the device in a breast pocket while using the head phones in winter clothing... in thinner clothing this disconnecting behavior is harder to reproduce for me.Use the Tone+ with a chest or arm pocket and don't let it stray too far from its connected devices. When you move out of range and drop connection some devices (My MBP for example) will require you to turn off the Tone+ and turn it back on. The previous model could handle a good 30 feet while this model seems to be limited to 10 feet.In spite of these problems, I still rate the device very high because it is the only device I've found on the market that will let me switch between two bluetooth devices, has good stereo sound, a good microphone, and very nice voice prompts. This version also features a very very useful *mute* feature you toggle on and off by holding down the volume up and down buttons simultaneously for a second. This and the form factor are worth any other hassles. Just make sure you have a chest  or arm pocket to carry it in when wearing a heavy jacket. The bluetooth antenna on this device seems to be on the left so a left side arm pocket is probably the best place for your cellphone.*tl;dr* for the price this device is fantastic (it is even better than some devices twice its price) but it has very poor range and won't work if you place enough of your body between the bluetooth transmitter and it.EDIT: Using the Tone+ with my cellphone is rather straight forward but, after some use I've figured out this process to get the MacBook Pro to use the audio headset at the same time as the cell phone: First complete the dual pairing procedure as documented in the LG Tone+ handbook starting with the MBP then the cell phone. Next: to start any dual use session 1) turn off bluetooth on all devices 2) turn on bluetooth on the MacBook Pro, 3) Turn on the LG Tone+ and select it as the audio out on the MacBook 4) turn on the Cell Phone's bluetooth and manually select the LG Tone+ You have to repeat steps 1 to 4 every time you start up any device, reboot, or walk out of range.

reviewText: Summary:  For next to nothing this is a great phone to have on hand for when you need one.We periodically host guests from overseas and many times they show up with a cell phone that doesn't work here or no phone at all.  Sometimes they're even scared of the "little talking people in the glowing box", but I digress.We had been using an old Nextel phone on T-Mobile that I got years ago for "free after rebate" as our guest phone.  However it was difficult to add time and didn't have a lot  of features.  For our most recent guest I decided to go all out and plunk down the money for this phone.  It was a great decision.Aside from the boatload of features and very easy to use interface it is durable and easy for anyone to add minutes at any time.  (I, or better yet our guests, can add minutes from the phone, a prepaid card, or by going to a website and clicking twice.  Better still, the 2x minutes work transparently and it winds up not costing a lot for the typical short calls and messages visitors are likely to make.The added benefit is that a week after our most recent guest left my wife had her phone stolen.  Having this on hand meant she could still make calls (using the minutes left over from our more recent guest... Score!) for the day it took before we could have it replaced.
title: LG 440G Prepaid Phone With Double Minutes (Tracfone)
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Cell Phones', 'No-Contract Cell Phones', 'Phones']]

reviewText: In this age of "Mensa Phones" - some folks don't NEED all that stuff. We certainly don't we needed a phone for emergency uses and such. This flip phone along with a prepaid card does EVERYTHING that we need it for, for a fraction of the cost of a "Uber Phone". Heck, the phone along with a years worth of minutes, was probably less than what a monthly charge could be for some people. Don't get me wrong, many people NEED all the bells and whistles. Since we still have a landline, (oh,,,now don't judge - it's a VIOPO based line, so, we are not THAT far into the dark ages! LOL), and since we also don't need the phone, for communications from the house a cell phone would go to waste - why pay for something, that  hardly ever gets used, for most of the month?The TracFone line, also has phones that are "smart phones" and have web based apps and such,,,the TracFone line of products, [to me], is a really GREAT way to save money, and budget for cell phone payments and costs. Children that are getting a phone for the first time, or, teenagers that text till the cows come home, can dig DEEP into a family budget,,,using the TracFone, teaches restraint as well, you can see how many minutes you have used, or have left  - its a great way, to teach younger folks, how to keep the texting and talking down, without unhappy 'surprises' on a bill, that you were not expecting to see that month!
title: LG 440G Prepaid Phone With Double Minutes (Tracfone)
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Cell Phones', 'No-Contract Cell Phones', 'Phones']]

reviewText: Was quite excited to find this phone with Net10 service at Amazon, (Amazing Amazon!), because, the Net10 750 minute card for $25.00, gives me the biggest bang for the buck, and web/data usage is just deducted from the minutes also. I wanted as "smart" a phone as I could get without being required to pay $40.00 or more per month for service, and the LG 840G fits the bill beautifully! I must admit that I don't tend to use the web on my phone all that much, but the screen is an acceptable size if I need to do so. The camera is great and I've sent photos to friends. ( I'm not a kid, and switched from a flip phone, to see if I could adjust to the touch screen, and it was so easy with this phone!) Texting is a "piece of cake", with the virtual qwerty keyboard. The service is key, though. Tracfone is great, (same family as Net10), as this phone, as a tracfone, has triple minutes for life, but if you require 500 or more minutes per month, this phone, wit Net10 service is the way to go. I like using a stylus with it, and Amazon has some great choices, (including some that connect to the phone so it is always handy), but the touch screen responds just as well to your fingertips. The LG840G may not be a smartphone, per se, but it is certainly smart enough for me, and, probably for many more people out there, who just wanna be a bit more updated and feel more connected to what everyone else is doing.
title: LG 840G Prepaid Phone (Net10)
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Cell Phones', 'No-Contract Cell Phones', 'Phones']]

reviewText: The LG Venice is a good phone limited by the slow Boost Mobile 3G network because it is NOT a 4G LTE phone and it can not connect to the high speed Boost 4G LTE network.  As of May 2014, the Venice has been replaced in the Boost lineup by the MUCH better Motorola Moto G, which is a 3G phone with a sharper screen, faster processor, and the newest Android software.If your neighborhood is served by the Boost 4G LTE network, do NOT buy the 3G Venice, instead buy a Boost 4G LTE phone that has ten times faster data speeds.  If your neighborhood does not have 4G, buy the much newer, much better 3G Moto G, which is the best 3G phone in the Boost lineup.The Venice runs all my favorite apps, such as Pandora Radio (using 3g) and Netflix (using wi-fi). The Venice has a single core processor, so it is NOT the best phone for demanding 3D action games.The front speaker is adequate when you are making a phone call in a quiet room, but can be shrill at maximum volume. The rear speaker sounds good at moderate volume levels, but becomes harsh when turned up to a loud volume.Music sounds great through high quality headphones or when streaming to a good bluetooth speaker.The rear camera takes good (not great) photos and adequate quality videos in bright sunlight. On cloudy days and indoors photos sometimes have muddy colors, with poor contrast and will lack sharpness. Locking the camera at ISO 100 outdoors and at ISO 200 indoors improves photo quality.Battery life can be great. You can get up to 24 hours per charge when you are using the LG power control bar on the drop down notification screen to turn OFF 3g, wifi, bluetooth, and GPS until they are actually needed. I turn on wifi a few times a day to download Gmail and check the news and weather, then I turn wifi back off.The pull-down power bar lets you "click" the screen brightness to 100% for outdoors and back to 50% level indoors, which greatly increases battery life. If you are watching Netflix at night, a brightness setting of just 20% work well and extends battery life.Using GPS navigation with 3G will drain your battery in about three hours. Connect the Venice to a high quality car charger (such as the Motorola fast charger) if you use GPS for more than an hour or two a day.Cases and Batteries: The LG Venice uses the same cases and batteries as do its siblings, the LG L7, and LG Splendor.Best Cases: Search Amazon for "Black Perforated Hybrid Case" for the LG Venice and LG L7.For MAXIMUM drop protection, which requires a thick, bulky, heavy case, search for "Ballistic SG LG L7" case or "Ballistic SG LG Splendor case.BOOST MOBILE COVERAGE MAP: Before you buy any Boost Mobile phone, carefully study the coverage map at the Boost Mobile website. The map enables you to zoom in for a block by block view of signal strength, to see the quality of the Boost signal on the block where you live and work. There is ZERO Boost coverage in some states, and ZERO Boost coverage in most rural area. Check the coverage map carefully before you buy any Boost Mobile phone.

reviewText: PLEASE SEE NOTE AT END.After lots of reading and asking lots of questions, this behind the times Potato Head bought his first smart phone, a phone now encased in a pink flowery case and used almost exclusively by Mrs.Spudman the queen of the technophobes.In the box there was no owner's manual, so I found one on the web, downloaded it, and printed it. Using the manual Mrs.Spudman figured out how to configure her phone, add and delete numbers, used the camera, text, add aps, and do all those things that others mostly take for granted.The clarity of the screen is terrific with crisp text and graphics. Photos taken with the phone are not state of the art, but are certainly good enough to send via email and post on Facebook.One important feature for us is the speaker phone because Mrs. Spudman hates to hold the phone to her ear during those marathon phone conversations of hers. The sound coming from the phone's speaker is good, what one might expect from a cell phone's tiny speaker. Using bluetooth we sometimes use the phone with a wireless speaker for better quality sound. On a side note, the external speaker on our daughter's iphone is not better than that on the LG Venice.On a ten hour drive to Georgia we used GPS for the first time ever. Again the non techie Mrs. Spudman figured out how to set up and use the GPS which verbalizes directions with a pleasant female voice. The GPS is up to date and uses a Tom Tom system. The GPS feature is wonderful and got us to Georgia and back and helped us navigate around Augusta confidently. We had one hiccup on the way back home driving through DC. Not sure where th fault lay but we missed a turn and got lost on the city streets. Thanks goodness the GPS rerouted us and we were soon back on course. Can't imagine what we'd have done without the help of the GPS.We did notice that the battery lost power quickly on the trip until we plugged it into a power source in our car.  On our last night in Augusta Mrs. Spudman didn't charge the phone, so we had only 14% battery power for our drive. We kept the phone plugged in on the drive and by the time we reached our next destination, the battery power was almost up to 90%. We used  the "Motorola Vehicle Power Adapter micro-USB Rapid Rate Charger" bought from Amazon. It's also a great product.Bottom line -  On the ten hour drive to Georgia we never lost our signal once. Boost has also been great, especially the diminishing monthly cost as long as one makes regular monthly payments on time. I like the phone so much that I WAS going to buy another one for myself.The internal memory on this phone has maxed out limiting what can be done on it. Also we got a message from Boost saying we'd maxed out our data usage. Mrs. Spudman spent an hour at Radio Shack with a helpful guy who got the phone to at least function better than a paper weight by deleting and moving stuff to the SD card.  He said the memory full problem is something he's been seeing with this model phone.UPDATE - Removing email has helped a lot with the memory glitch.
title: LG Venice (Boost Mobile)
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Cell Phones', 'No-Contract Cell Phones', 'Phones']]

reviewText: I am actually obsessed with this phone!!! I Love the price it was $20-40 cheaper than the ones they are selling in Boost Mobile stores + Boostmobile.com. I really enjoy it. reviewText: The L9 was a very good phone back in 2012, but it has now been replaced by the $49 LG Optimus L70, sold by T-Mobile's MetroPcs stores and at the MetroPcs website. reviewText: I'm with T-Mobile and needed a new phone.  I have a Samsung Galaxy S4 Mini international phone(great phone by the way), but it doesn't have WIFI calling (only T-Mobile branded phones do) and that feature is very important to me.  I got the LG Optimus L9 and gave the Samsung to my wife.  Here is my review.It's what's called a mid-level phone.  The high-level phones have faster processors, better screens, more memory, 4G LTE, features like auto-brightness - the list goes on.  My take on this phone?  I love it.The screen is great.  It's sharp and touches, drags, and scrolls are very smooth.  It has T-Mobile's old 4G data, which is really HPSA+.  It's plenty fast for me and supposedly, HPSA+ doesn't drain your battery as fast as LTE.  Speaking of batteries, this phone has a great one.  Poor battery life is one of the  knocks on this phone, but once I disabled all the bloatware wakelocks. it lasts all day and typically has 80%-90% left.Speaking of bloatware, this phone is loaded.  Every product Google ever made for phones is on it, along with a ton of T-Mobile ...stuff.  I took them off the desktop and disabled their access to the Internet where possible and it's fine, but if it really bothers you, root it and do away with them completely.Call quality is excellent on both ends of the call whether using the phone microphone or a headset.  The external speaker isn't the best, but it's good enough for calls, and I don't use it for anything else.  The processor isn't as fast as the ones in more expensive phones, but I'm not crunching databases here, I'm making calls, checking my email, and occasionally browsing the Internet.  It's plenty fast for that.I I was worried about listening to music with the L9, but using Poweramp and my Klipsch earbuds, it actually sounds clearer than it did with the Galaxy.One thing you'll notice if you buy this phone is the Optimus theme wallpaper is awful and there are only 4 themes.  If you don't like the choices, you can always use a favorite picture, and there are plenty of themes and wallpaper available on Google Play.  I went with a solid,dark blue background.I bought this phone because it was 1/3 the price of the high end phones, but I don't think I'm missing anything.  It's as good for my purposes as any phone I have owned.  Highly recommended.
title: LG Optimus L9 P769 4GB Android Smartphone - T-Mobile
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Cell Phones', 'Unlocked Cell Phones']]

reviewText: (Note:Avoid sellers import verison that don't include the US 1-Year Warranty. Look at the seller policy hyperlink first before running the risk of getting screwed. Web Browsing with a removable battery($20 Spare and Charger).+Pop in a mircoSIM card and your ready to go phone.  Unlock-able after 40 days of T-Mobile service.+Very fast Ti dual core with 1GB RAM, small 4GB Storage.  Performs like a turbocharge 4cyc family sedan and comparable to the 2011 Samsung Galaxy S2. Will have trouble with desktop websites.+Sharp 229ppi 4.5 inch Bright IPS-LCD screen with No Auto Dim.+A joy to use with the layout of the buttons and menu navigation.  A good balance between simple iPhone and bloated Samsung Android phone.+Wifi signal and calls are clear with fast 23mbps 3G HSPC datalink.  GPS signal is OK to Good.+Good selection of $6 cases and endless Android apps.-Major CON- Only has 4GB(1.8 App Usable) storage. Your have to root the device to get 2GB+ apps to save on the SD card slot. For non-Rooted phones, you can cache large data on the SD card slot.-CON-Mobile site are very fast, but the full-size desktop websites can slow the phone down..Usable camera with slight noise and camcorder.  Will not beat the Nokia 521 in this department..Audio and speaker are OK..Nice design and durable weight for HQ plastic phone.Precautions-Based with many online complaints, stick with the original version 4.0 ICS software for better battery life and less errors.  Don't update to 4.1 JB just yet. Wait for 4.1.2 or 4.2.-Avoid using NONE genuine chargers that cause a possible fire over nightRecommended Apps/Accessories to make the phone much better+Cache App Data on the SD card in the App Setting.+32GB Sandisk/Samsung SD card. May fit 64GB with right exFAT format.+$2 Swiftkey or AI Keyboard App+FREE-Boat Web Browser or Dolipin Mini  Web Browser+$20 for 2 spare batteries and a charger for the frequent traveler.

reviewText: I bought this as T-mobile wants $240 for the same phone.  It arrived brand new in the T-mobile box, with all manuals, a micro SIM card (so you don't need to buy or cut down one), charger and cable.  I took it to a local T-mobile shop with a micro SD card I had from my previous phone and they quickly fired it up and switched my phone number to it.  I added the $10 for an extra 2Gb of data which also allows the wireless hotspot to be used.Pros:-Size very thin and light, little wasted space around the screen.-4G is quite fast though it varies depending on location.  At home I get 12Mbps down and 6Mbps up.  It's been as low as 1/6 of that various other places I've checked (using the speedtest.net app).-The hotspot transfers every bit of that speed to a tablet signed in to it.-Extremely good GPS.  Better than any other phone I've had (tested using GPS Test app).-Call clarity and controls are good.-Screen is very clear and responsive.-Bluetooth pairs quickly with no issues.Cons:-Storage: 1.8G, lot's of bloatware that can't be removed.-Speaker: Not very loud.Neither Pro nor Con:-Battery life.  I can generally go a whole day without having to charge.  It uses micro USB to charge so just keep spare cables in the vehicle and at work.I'm very pleased with this purchase.

reviewText: First of all, yes it's a good phone; and it probably has the longest battery life of most smart phones.However, the 300-480 hours of standby time promoted on websites, actually is only 48 hours when doing absolutely nothing with it, and leaving the phone in an area with very good reception.When being in a bad reception area, or use the phone for very light work, the battery goes down to 24 hours.When playing very light games, like cardgames, or browsing the internet, it goes down to 8-13 hours of use.3D Games last between 4-6 hours; and most chargers won't be able to keep up with charging the battery AND providing enough power to the phone to not lose battery at the same time.Second MAJOR reason NOT to buy this phone, is because it comes with 1,6GB of internal memory.Android used to fit on 800MB of memory, but 4.1 uses over 1,2GB of this 1,6GB of memory; leaving you with a good ~200 MB of memory left for a good 10 to 15 apps; or about 2 or 3 games.Every system update, or apps update will result in 'out of memory' messages, and forcing you to uninstall smaller apps.Many pre-installed apps can't be uninstalled, even if you wanted it, and can't even be disabled (some of the T-mobile apps), and keep on downloading updates that you will never need.This phone came with Android 4.1, and was outdated the day 4.1.2 came out, due to lack of memory!Apps to move data to the SD card won't work in 4.1+Generally the external SD card is only for audio, video, or personal photos.DON'T BUY!IF YOU GO ANDROID, MAKE SURE YOU GOT MORE THAN 2GB OF INTERNAL MEMORY AVAILABLE, 2.5 or 3GB MINIMUM RECOMMENDED!!!
title: LG Optimus L9 P769 4GB Android Smartphone - T-Mobile
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Cell Phones', 'Unlocked Cell Phones']]

reviewText: I purchased this as a backup device until the Google edition of the S4 comes out.  At first I was pleased with the speed and cost, but over time I realized the phone has many shortcomings.First, the L9 (LG-P769) is near impossible to root.  Out of all the android devices I've had I had this is the only one I've chosen to not root because the method looks too difficult.  Two, the Jelly Bean update has been pulled by T-Mobile with little hope it'll ever come back.  LG has a terrible reputation of supporting their devices and since I can't get the phone rooted a custom ROM is no longer an option.  Three, it only has a 21Mbit/s radio.  This didn't seem like a big deal at first but the difference between it and the 42Mbit/s radio I had in my old S3 is huge.  The L9 only sees about 2.5Mbit/s down when the S3 saw closer to 10Mbit/s.  The latency is the same but it feels much slower because of the throughput.  Last, the device doesn't have a light sensor or an LED notification light.  I knew the LG didn't have these but I didn't realize giving these up would be such a big deal.  Neither of these are expensive parts and including them wouldn't have added much to cost/price.Overall I can't recommend this device.
title: LG Optimus L9 P769 4GB Android Smartphone - T-Mobile
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Cell Phones', 'Unlocked Cell Phones']]

reviewText: I am on an old T-Mobile family plan, not the pre-paid plans they are trying to sell now. This phone works with the old plan; you just have to transfer your SIM card. If you have a micro-SIM, just put it into the new phone. If you have a regular SIM, you can change the account to the (included) micro SIM at T-Mobile's website.I have used it to watch videos on YouTube, Skype, take and post pictures on Facebook, navigate, deposit a check with the Chase bank app, text, and surf the internet. It even makes phone calls!The phone is quick and the screen looks great. The plastic backing feels nice, but I will probably get a protective case for it soon anyway. The battery lasted about 20 hours with Wi-Fi and GPS turned on with heavy usage. I imagine that light users would get 24+ hours of battery life easily.This phone is the best for users who want a quality unit without paying a lot of money. Most people probably already have Wi-Fi at home, work, and school, so you probably don't have to buy a data plan. If you truly need to peruse LOLCats at the grocery store, T-Mobile does of course have data plans available, but I can't comment on them. I only use shared minutes, unlimited texting, and Wi-Fi, and it works out quite well. The Google Navigation will even work for short trips as long as you input the address while you are still in Wi-Fi range.To summarize: you can buy a great phone for under $200 and use it with your existing T-Mobile plan, even if you don't currently have a data connection. I can confirm it works admirably for calls, texting, apps, photos, and Wi-Fi.
title: LG Optimus L9 P769 4GB Android Smartphone - T-Mobile

reviewText: Given the price and performance of the LG Optimus L9 (model LG-P769), I would have loved this phone, save for one simple problem. Its internal memory, otherwise known as ROM, is, as you know, only 4GB. That wouldn't be so bad if you could offset that 4GB with a 32GB Sandisk card (for about $32 extra, or less). However, what you don't know, and can't know until/unless you actually have the phone in your hands and you actually log into your Google Play account to download an app, is that you, essentially, can't download any apps, because you have far less than 1 GB, depending on what apps come pre-loaded on your phone (mine has only 600 MB of truly-free available space). They operating system "says" you have 1.8GB of usable space, but, that comes pre-loaded with 600MB of what turns out to be non-removeable bload. Note this very clearly, that 600 MB of pre-loaded applications can NOT be deleted. It can't even be moved to the 32-GB micro-sd card. It's there forever (save a jailbreak, which is the only way to make this phone usable). Nobody will tell you this ahead of time, so, mark my words and see for yourself if you already own this phone. You can not move or delete the pre-loaded apps (most of which are useless, and which are listed below). In a very short time, your remaining 600 MB of internal memory will be used up with apps, and, after that, you're stuck. It's a brick at that point. You can't download any new apps directly to the SD card, so, you're stuck.  In summary, all the specs of the phone are for naught if you can't put apps on it. So, it's worthless. I'm going to use mine as a test case for my first jailbreak, and, if I brick it by mistake, there is no real loss, it's that worthless.  The non-removable apps that T-Mobile preloads on this phone are provided to me, by T-Mobile, and are as follows:411 & moreAlarm/clockAmazonApplication managerBackupBrowserCalculatorCalendarCaller TunesCamcorderCameraChromeCMASContactsDownloadsEmailFacebookFile managerFileShareGalleryGame BaseGamesGmailGoogleGoogle settingsGoogle+LocalLookout SecurityMapsMemoMessagingMessengerMusicNavigationPhonePlay BooksPlay MagazinesPlay Movies & TVPlay MusicPlay StorePolaris Office 4ScoutSettingsSetupSlacker RadioSmartphone Mobile HotspotSmartShareT-Mobile My AccountT-Mobile Name IDT-Mobile TVTalkTask ManagerVideosVisual VoicemailVoice RecorderVoice SearchWeatherYouTube
title: LG Optimus L9 P769 4GB Android Smartphone - T-Mobile
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Cell Phones', 'Unlocked Cell Phones']]

reviewText: I've benefited from Buyers Reviews, but I prefer a CNET, PCMag or Consumer Reports type reviews by technical evaluaters who are more competent. Buyers are valuable in writing about user and personal experience.  I excerpted Consumer Rport's review of the phone.  I bought the L9 under T-Mobile's new plan model where the plan (no contract) is priced according, $50/month for voice/data/ message and you pay the retail price for the phone.  TM priced the L9 at $241 plus tax (04/12/2013).  If you "bring your own phone" you buy the SIM card for $10.I had a MyTouch 4G (by HTC) which was highly rated, but my experience was just "OK".  My wife has the same phone but in White, and it is mostly useful in our house; however, HER data & message service is mostly unavailable while my handset was sensitive enough. I can't explain why 2 exact phones (except color) would perform so differently.The LG L9 seems to be worse than my MyTouch 4G in signal sensitivity -- the L9 has 4 bars, and typically only 1 bar would show (I haven't compared the db readings), and data service is very spotty in my brick house (data calls would time out 50% of the time).  I am considering returning it to T-Mobile and eating the re-stocking charge (maybe it's waived in 14 days, I have to read the sales contract); the poor reception is very aggravating.It is, however, the least expensive 4G data, Android 4.0 phone; the Samsung's are now price like iPhone's and they don't seem to have more functionality than other 4G data & 4.0 phones.The menu steps are significantly different from my previous Android 2.0 phone.  One dialing feature I REALLY miss is that I could type in the first 1-3 letters of my contact list, and my HTC phone would show in a speed list.  The LG Phone doesn't have this function which is a major inconvenience.The LG has "touch" buttons (instead of mechanical) for Back & Menu; looks neat ?  but it isn't.  The buttons are not lit, and I rather have "hard" buttons than hidden "soft" buttons.(The back is plastic which keeps the weight low; it's textured so it's doesn't feel cheap as it is cheap manufacturing.)______________________________________________CR's TakeThe LG Optimus L9 offers an impressive blend of intriguing features and apps in a thin and lightweight package.Highs* 4.5-inch high-resolution display with excellent quality* Top-notch ease of use, messaging, and Web browsing* Quick Memo lets you use your finger to scribble notes on anything you see on the phone's screen* Allows you to launch apps such as a camera, messages, or phone directly from a locked screen* Supports fast 4G data networks* Can snap a still image while recording a video* Front-facing camera facilitates video chats and self-portraits* Uses versatile Android operating system, with access to many apps and services<Lows* Video recording is mediocre* Lacks a physical button for quick phone access, and its virtual keypad makes it hard to enter a number without looking* Lacks Flash video* Memory card is hard to accessDetailed test resultsThe LG Optimus L9 has an excellent-quality 4.5-inch, high-resolution, touch-screen display packed in a relatively thin and lightweight case. It includes Quick Memo, a pull-down menu option app that lets you use your finger to scribble notes on anything you see on the phone's screen, from photos, e-mails, and calendar appointments to the home screen itself. The finished "memo" actually becomes a picture that you can easily e-mail or text to other, as well as share on social networks. The Optimus L9 provides easy access to all main functions via a highly responsive touch screen that supports five home screens of apps, programmable shortcuts, as well as a home button flanked by menu and back keys. The Optimus L9 also provides a straightforward way to add apps, widgets, or change wallpaper. You simply press and hold a blank spot on the screen to summon a Lazy Susan-style buffet of home screens, apps, widgets and other customization options. Pressing and holding the home key launches a stack of screen shots of your most recently used apps. Tap any one of them, and you can jump to that app. You can also launch the phone, messaging, e-mail, or camera app directly from a locked screen without the need to first unlock the screen. You do this by swiping upward on any one of app icons that are visible on the locked screen. But this phone lacks the search key found on many Android phones.The Optimus L9 lets you perform Google searches by voice command, and lets you download applications, services, and games, and more from the Google Play Store. Its multi-touch screen lets you zoom in and out of photos or Web pages using two fingers (for instance, your thumb and index finger). It also has a handy on-screen drop-down status bar that alerts you to and takes you to new messages, upcoming appointments, and other items that need your attention, even when your screen is locked. Its Android OS offers better text editing tools and controls for managing data usage, and enhanced voice-activated navigation and dictation. High-speed "4G" wireless broadband data capability provides faster Web browsing and file downloads. The faster network also facilitates better Web browsing experiences. The Wi-Fi connection provides another way to access the Web, e-mail, and other Internet-based content, without using your data plan allowance. But this model lacks Flash video.MESSAGING: The virtual keyboard was very easy to use. This phone comes with common preset text messages, and also allows you to create custom preset text messages for your individual special situations or frequent use. Excellent e-mail readability and attachment capabilities. This phone allows you to edit Word documents and Excel spreadsheets out of the box, which can come in handy when working on the go. The Optimus L9 also supports Microsoft Exchange and Outlook for work e-mail. When connected to Windows or Macintosh computers, this phone can appear on the computer as another drive. You can then transfer data to and from your phone as you could on a regular drive.PHONE: We tested this phone under a variety of conditions to simulate environments ranging from the quiet indoors to noisy roadsides. It had very good voice quality when talking, good when listening. Talk time was an ample 7.5 hours. This phone has a very good mixture of controls and features for making and taking calls. Excellent keypad readability under most lighting conditions, even in bright light. Its voice command allows you to conveniently dial numbers from your phone book by speaking the name, without the usual training. You can also dial numbers by pronouncing the digits. It has Bluetooth for wireless hands-free voice communication. This model can simultaneously be on a phone call and an Internet-based connection over the cellular network. Can be used internationally. But this model lacks a physical button for quick phone access, and its virtual keypad makes dialing difficult without looking. Auto answer doesn't work with headset.MULTIMEDIA: The 5-megapixel camera has a short shutter lag, and produced good pictures at ISO settings up to 400. Camera has a flash, autofocus, manual ISO settings, smile detection, and can record HD video. Its touch focus feature lets you override the autofocus by tapping on any subject on the screen. You can even take a picture by just saying "cheese". The camera's flash and ISO-setting controls help improve your chances of taking better pictures under low-light conditions. Its face detection comes in handy when you're snapping pics of babies, toddlers, or other fussy subjects. You can also snap a still picture at any moment while shooting a video. The front-facing VGA camera allows easy self-portraits, and can support video chats. But the camera took only fair 1080p video, OK only for the most casual uses.The music player has the capabilities and controls of a typical stand-alone MP3 player, including an equalizer, music shuffle and repeat controls and options for sorting music by album, artist, etc. This model also supports Bluetooth stereo headsets, and can download music over the phone network. Its Bluetooth data support enables the phone to wirelessly share pictures, contacts, and other files with compatible printers, computers, and mobile devices.GPS navigation capability provides spoken turn-by-turn directions and automatic re-routing. The Optimus L9 supports the Digital Living Network Alliance (DLNA) standard via its SmartShare application. This lets the phone connect via Wi-Fi to share content with other compatible certified devices such as a TV, printer, and computer. The Optimus L9 can act as a mobile hotspot for up to eight Wi-Fi-enabled devices. It also supports Wi-Fi calling. It has 4GB of built-in memory, and supports memory cards of up to 32GB. Its memory capacity is beneficial for storing music, videos, pictures, and other types of files. But the memory card is hard to access.About - LG Optimus L9The LG Optimus L9 is a smart phone designed for use on the T-Mobile network, including its HSPA+ "4G" network. It can also be used internationally.It has a 4.5-inch touch-screen display, measures 5.0 by 2.6 by 0.4 inches and weighs 4.2 ounces. It runs on the Android operating system.The Optimus L9 has a 5-megapixel camera that can record high-definition video, a front-facing camera, and a music player. It also features a virtual QWERTY keyboard that's useful for messaging and Web searches. This phone has Wi-Fi, Bluetooth for wireless hands-free communication, DLNA, and GPS navigation capability. Web browsing, e-mail, and texting capabilities are also included. It can act as a mobile hotspot for Wi-Fi-enabled devices.This LG phone has a standard 3.5mm jack. It has 4GB of built-in memory, and supports memory cards of up to 32GB
title: LG Optimus L9 P769 4GB Android Smartphone - T-Mobile

reviewText: Pretty much had all the phones you can imagine. I break them I sell them and LG L9 is what I keep as mybackup.These days it's my first phone after I am finally done with all the 4.7"+ android crap and currently have no idea what to buy next (Z1 compact was promising but turned out to be pure crap. The same for moto x).L9 fits your hand just right - it's actually very slim and not so wide for an 4.5" screen. The rubberized plastic cover makes the grip perfect - whenever I take this phone I feel this is the right one. The phone also has the stellar battery life. I get almost 4 days out of it, with Juice Defender periodic polling. The LCD is just great - no fancy HD crap that consumes battery and offers nothing - this one is brighter than any crap from Samsung yet it offers the same sharpens (in fact I prefer IPS over Amoled - I don't need fancy and fake punchy colors but nicely readable text - this is better than HD Amoled on any Samsung I tried. Moto x had amoled screen which is even worse).The bad thing about this phone is it's low level specs. This just can't be a pro phone. It doesn't have enough memory and the CPU is slow. You just need more. After two years I am still looking for a phone that will add very little changes to L9: some 512MB of RAM more, any CPU but this OMAP and a bit brighter LCD. We are talking about a 200$ phone that sadly doesn't exist. Moto G is too crappy and bulky, HTC one mini with its battery cant be a pro phone, Z1 compact - that's sony - never-ending gimmicks that don't work. Iphone - well I need proper notifications and proper data toggling like juice defender does, otherwise that's not a phone I can depend (battery wise and critical notifications wise - no perioidic audio notification or blinking led or blinking lcd. That means you need to join a group of 100million idiots who paid hefty for this phone and then are constantly checking on the phone if there was any notification, instead of notification being just that - a notification).

reviewText: Wow! What a great phone. I have an LG Optimus G Pro locked to ATT that I use in the US. I needed a replacement for my awful Galaxy SIII for international travel. The SIII had a terrible camera. The photos were washed out whenever there was indirect sunlight. The SIII screen would lock up regularly, particularly just when trying to take a quick photo shot. So the SIII had to go. It was stolen in Colombia. So that put me in the market for a replacement. I love the LG Optimus G Pro. But it's still locked in contract and is really too big to be packed around the world. The Optimus G is just right. It's a nice size that fits easily in a belt case. The G is just as smooth and fast as the G Pro. The WiFi is strong and connects easily. Battery life is very good. I regularly get two days between charges under heavy use with the G. It will last about a week if just sitting on standby while I use the G Pro. The G audio is very good. I listen to both an extensive music collection and audio books on the G. For international travel in which I will be regularly trading SIM cards I like that the SIM slot on the G is accessible behind a cover on the side of the phone. You never take the back off the phone. It's easy to swap both SIM cards and MicroSD cards. The back of the phone is glass and quite slippery. It needs a protective case. I've got a hard case on mine which makes one handed use easy.I picked up my used G that is like new for a very good price. The latest news is that Kit Kat is coming to the G. It works fine on Jelly Bean. But it's nice to know it will get the latest operating system. I'm very happy with this phone. Some phones don't age well. The Optimus G was released in late 2012. It's a great phone that is still cutting edge in both hardware and software. I'll have this one for a long time.
title: LG Optimus G E970 Unlocked 4G LTE Quad-Core ! 4.7" IPS 2GB 16GB ROM Phone
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Cell Phones', 'Unlocked Cell Phones']]

reviewText: LG has always made a quality phones.  This phone is no different and their hardware is top of the line.  Feel and look is of a high end phone and specs are all top notch.  Phone is really fast and I was able to buy brand new on sale for $186.  For that price it beat all other phones for similar specs.  Only thing I don't like about LG phones is that they really don't care about upgrading your firmware after they sell the phone, which is a shame because their phones are really capable of great things.  For the same price this phone would be a much better choice than Motorola Moto G or even Blu Life Pure Mini (I own both).
title: LG Optimus G E970 Unlocked 4G LTE Quad-Core ! 4.7" IPS 2GB 16GB ROM Phone

reviewText: The jump has been great, starting because Android has all the applications and for having in this world (that's what actually matters). The phone is very fast to download and upload files due to its 4G LTE 900Mhz and 2100Mhz, its 32GB of internal storage is more than enough to download endless apps and place all the music you want (not to mention bring disadvantage microSD memory port for it is absurd). The HD resolution True HD IPS LCD screen is pretty good although I prefer my special Super AMOLED screens because I am a born player, in this case the phone plays best natural tones (to view photos or videos) but it is not suitable screen to play. The size, thickness and design is among the best. Speaking of speed, 4-core processor with 2GB of RAM make excelentemete his work (I have not had setbacks with many applications open at the same time, with all that, if I have a 500MB of free RAM). I only thing I miss in this phone is a dedicated camera button and what I can talk bad is precisely the quality of it, despite having a camera sensor 13Mpx leaves much to be desired, not bad, but could be better (I've had camera phones 8Mpx best). In conslusion, for the price. . . this phone is the best deal out there in the market, is the phone with the best performance / value....

reviewText: Its a brand new phone with high configuration, in generic packaging. Includes 16GB microSD card & updated firmware to Jelly Bean 4.1.2 :-). What more you need!!!? & I paid $187 for it (on 29 Jan, 2014). BUT, I received this phone today (10th Feb)!!! Shipping was terrible. It supposed to be delivered on 6th Feb, but... :-|. I was very angry!!! but when I opened the box... wow! it was an awesome experience!!! I definitely recommend this phone!!!Edit (24 Feb, 2014): Still flawless performance after 24 days of power usage. You just can not ask anything more on 'performance' department. I could not utilize 2GB RAM, it is more than enough. Quad core CPU is super fast. I see many users complaining about battery life. Well 2100mAH is not enough for a android device like Optimus G to run 24 hours on moderate use. However, you can get that much of battery life by turning on 'Eco Mode' from setting menu. And about camera performance, it is doing pretty well. Images are fairly sharp enough, though the front facing camera is not that sharp. But you have to consider its price. In this price, this phone is the best phone ever!!! I still, highly recommend this phone.

reviewText: I bought this charger at $49.99 and when it arrived it had a sticker on one side that said $39.99. Bad luck there, but well. Talking about the product itself, it charges surprisingly fast and the convenience you get is great. I have it on my bedside table and when I go to sleep, I just leave my Nexus on it and when I get up, I see the yellow light which means it has stopped charging. That is great because it doesn't overcharge the battery. It knows when it's full and it stops the charge. Despite this, it doesn't get discharged, so I believe when it goes to 99% it restarts charging until it's full. I charged my Nexus with my computer, but this one is way faster, way. However, the only disadvantage of wireless charging Qi is that the battery heats. The first time I charged the phone with this charger, it got alarmingly hot, I took it off as soon as I touch it and felt the heat. But the next times, until today, it doesn't heat much, if at all.I totally reccommend this product to anyone willing to spend $50 for the convenience of wireless charging.
title: LG Electronics WCP-300 Wireless Charging Pad - Retail Packaging - Black
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Chargers', 'Cell Phone Docks']]

reviewText: Having come from a Palm Pre with their TouchStone wireless charging system, I really missed the convenience of wireless charging.  Now I have it again with my Verizon LG G2!  This works just as well as the old Palm system, although I miss two things: the phone on the LG charging pad sits flat on the table rather than angled up, so it is harder to read the phone from my bed while lying down.  Second, there are no magnets to hold the phone in place and line it up like there were with the Palm. To be fair, though, the alignment doesn't appear to be too finicky and seems to charge as long as it is within an half inch of perfectly aligned.One other minor complaint is that the green/yellow LED on the pad is super bright and I had to cover it to sleep at night.
title: LG Electronics WCP-300 Wireless Charging Pad - Retail Packaging - Black
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Chargers', 'Cell Phone Docks']]

reviewText: Bought this locally at the Verizon store since no one else had it in store other than online for $40. Little weird buying from them since I've been with AT&T for 10 years but oh well. Works great with my LG Optimus G Pro, looks good and works as soon as I lay it on top in any direction, charges pretty quick. Has led light that goes from orange to green when charging. Make sure you use the included charging cord and not some third party cheaper android charger it won't work. Also make sure if you have a after market phone cover that it has a Qi charging receiver on the back of it (looks like a flat doughnut with tape over it). Otherwise it will not work.
title: LG Electronics WCP-300 Wireless Charging Pad - Retail Packaging - Black
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Chargers', 'Cell Phone Docks']]

reviewText: Most awesome unnecessary tech gizmo I've ever bought.  Instead of fiddling my phone off of my nightstand in the morning and trying to do it quietly before my wife wakes up, I just pick up the phone.  When I want it back on the charger, I set it down, centered on the charger.With my Nexus 5, this doesn't heat the phone up at all, and charges the phone completely while I sleep.  I've never had trouble getting the "sweet spot"; the entire back-middle of the phone works, it seems.One note; while it's not charging, there's a yellow light on the front.  While it's charging, that light turns green and blinks.  That could be annoying on the bedside.  That said, I may just move this to my desk at work; during the day, I won't see the blink, but it lets me pick up and set down my probably-too-large phone when I stop at my desk, and keep the thing charged all the time.Will probably give these out for Christmas presents to family; they're just damn good.
title: LG Electronics WCP-300 Wireless Charging Pad - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I purchased this to use with my LG Nexus 4. What attracted me to this charger was the small size and understated looks. I also liked the fact that there was no beeping sound when you placed the phone on the charger like some models. The LED blinks amber when charging and turns green when the phone is charged.I've used this several times and it has always worked well. Like with any phone capable of wireless charging, there is an acceptable range of where you can place the phone on the charger. Just be sure to place the phone on correctly each time and it should work great. I've found that with the Nexus 4 charging is about 15-20% slower than using the wall adapter. I usually charge the phone overnight so that doesn't matter to me. I guess you sacrifice some speed for convenience.After using this for a couple of weeks, I ended up purchasing an LG windshield mount specifically designed for this charger for use in the car. No more plugging/unplugging when I use my phone as a GPS in the car.I have no experience with other wireless chargers but this seems pretty good as far as wireless charges go. The price is reasonable and the unit is very small. It's worth checking out if you're in the market for a wireless charger.
title: LG Electronics WCP-300 Wireless Charging Pad - Retail Packaging - Black
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Chargers', 'Cell Phone Docks']]

reviewText: Amazon vendor Orion Gadgets delivered the battery in just four days in a well padded envelope.  It is a genuine LG battery, identical to the LG battery that came with my LG Venice (the same LG battery is used in the LG Splendor, Showtime and the LG L7).The OEM BL-44JH battery from Orion Gadgets was stamped with a LG factory "fresh date" that was less than six months old...a MUCH newer battery than I have received in the past from other Amazon vendors.However, the battery was DOA, totally dead on arrival, with a zero charge level.  A properly stored phone battery should be shipped with a charge of 30% to 50%, which ensures the battery will have a long lifespan. Orion Gadgets, are you listening?After four hours of charging, the battery was restored to 100% capacity. With a few days of use and three or four recharges, the new LG battery provides about the same time between charges as the original LG battery that came with my Venice. (Three hours of Netflix on wi-fi or GPS navigation using 3g, or up to 24 hours per charge for a few brief phone calls and texting).You can buy three LG batteries from Orion Gadgets for the price of just one at the Sprint or Boost Mobile store.  A real bargain.
title: LG BL44JH 1700mAh Original OEM Battery for the LG Motion 4G MS770/Optimus L7/P700/P750/Splendor/Venice - Non-Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I saw this set on a Verizon rep at the Verizon store.  I found the best price on Amazon.  I read many reviews before deciding to order it.  I wanted something that could control my smart phone (Samsung Galaxy S3) without taking the phone out of my pocket.  I can pause music when someone wants to talk to me, answer phone calls, call up 'S Voice' and give voice commands such as 'call someone', bring up apps, look up stuff on Google, etc.  It's not perfect but I probably haven't perfected usage of it yet - I'm not too techy.  It was easy to pair with my phone.  The tone quality is good for my purposes, phone calls sound good.  I like that when I take the earpieces out of my ears they don't fall to the ground - they're on a short tether and can be stuck into their 'garages'.  They're comfortable on my (very sensitive) neck - I forget I have them on.  No - they won't stay on when I'm doing my Pilates exercises on my back, but I found I can tie a scarf around them then to hold them.  One could also tuck them under ones shirt.  I'm not sure about the 33 foot range - they buzz when I get out of range of my phone, which happens sooner if I walk around a corner from my phone.  Keeps me from forgetting to bring along my phone!  I find that I prefer wearing these to the iPhone earbuds I have to wear when listening to my iPod Nano 6 (which isn't Bluetooth enabled).  Only one pair of rubber covers came with my model but they are sufficiently comfortable and stay in my ears pretty well.I highly recommend these.
title: Lg Tone+ Hbs730 Bluetooth Headset Bulk Packaging
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Cases', 'Basic Cases']]

reviewText: I have been looking for a great stereo Bluetooth headset that allowed me to listen to music, not worry about ear buds falling out and also support multiple devices.The LG Tone met these needs, had no issues with ear buds falling out and decent sound, not as solid a sound as preferred.  Unlike other headsets it also supported multiple devices so could switch between calls easily, there are not many multipoint stereo headsets so was excited to try this one.The headset is comfortable, was reluctant at first to have the band round my neck but felt ok, controls are a little awkward to get but better than others I have tried.  There are buttons to play/pause, advance and back tracks, volume up/down, pick up call and a power on/off switch.The headset vibrates when powered on and also when you receive calls, which is nice when ear buds are not in your ears.  They are housed by magnetic clips at each end of the neck band.The pairing was very easy and reconnected fine, adding another device was easy and could switch between without needing to use the phones Bluetooth settings.My issue that gave it low stars, is the microphone.  I tried many times, inside and outside but constant complaint was either can't hear you or sounds like in a metal box.  If this is an issue with the one I purchased then hope others have better luck.
title: Lg Tone+ Hbs730 Bluetooth Headset Bulk Packaging

reviewerName: Aliza M. Beer "Books & Belongings By Beverly ...
reviewText: What Ultra has that Tone+ doesn’t:The Tone+ (HBS-730) weighs 1.16oz. Ultra has shaved off some weight at 1.03oz. Despite this, the way the Ultra is shaped and weighted, it actually feels heavier in your hands and around your neck at first. You get used to it if it falls just right over your collarbone and neck.The LG website doesn’t list them but we can assume that the Ultra comes with the call waiting, call reject, last number redial, auto reconnect, multipoint connection (Advanced in Ultra’s case), Easy Pairing, Battery Status Alert, etc that all came with the Tone+. According to the LG website's lovely comparison chart though, the Ultra doesn’t offer calling waiting, call reject, last number redial, auto connect, voice activated dialing, battery status alert, easy pairing, A2DP (Advanced Audio Disribution) or AVRCP (Audio/Voice Remote Control Profile). So, no promises here.The talk time is 15 hours for the Tone+ but now only “up to ten hours” for the Ultra. But the Standby Time now promises up to 20 days vs. the 15 days for the Tone+. Music Play is still up to 10 hours for both. Charging time is the same at less than 2 hours. I regularly charge my Tone+ and I use it for phone calls and the gym and on-the-go so the five hours less doesn't do me too much damage in the long run.Of course, with the lightweight comes only VERY SLIGHTLY different dimensions but with an altogether different look:The Tone+ is5.34" (W) x 6.59” (L) x 0.67” (H)but the Ultra is5.34” (W) X 6.30” (L) X 0.55” (H)Both also share the memory flex strap with magnetic ear bugs that we know and love but that the Ultra now refers to as the trademarked 3D NeckBehind (Around-the-Neck Wearing Style with Body-Contoured Fit) Design. As someone who suffers from chronic neck pain, I was skeptical when I purchased my Tone+ but now I cannot imagine any other headphones for phone calls and the gym! Expect the same level of comfort from the Ultra...except that if you're upgrading from a Tone+, it might take a little getting used to the different feel.The Ultra now has Google Voice Actions Integration which may or may not be a necessity for iPhone users. I easily access Siri often using the headset.Though both claim noise reduction and echo reduction, Ultra goes as far as to say that it has ANC (Ambient Noise Cancellation) and the new JBL Signature Sound and the aforementioned Advanced Multipoint. And yes, the ANC is a big deal. I noticed a major difference not just in phone calls but particularly in sound quality. This upgrade wants you to believe that even bluetooth headphones can offer you the best sound for your tunes.Ironically, on the LG website, the Tone+ is beating the Ultra slight in reviews with 4.5/5 happy reviewers vs. 4.4/5. So it’s just a schmidgen. But really, it gives the Tone+ 92% positive reviews and the Ultra only 80%. I would take this with a grain of salt considering that only a handful have reviewed the new Ultra and thousands have reviewed the Tone+. Likely the price is a deterrent for some people. I've had my Tone+ headset for a while (as has my husband) and we drag them around all over the place and they still work and look just like new. So, yeah, the Ultra is almost twice the price of the LG Tone depending on where you get it. And as the LG Tone stands up to time fairly easily you may not need (but you may want) an upgrade.Owners have said that the Tone Ultra is much more Android friendly than the Tone+ which is very iPhone friendly and go as far as offering that you stick to the Tone+ if you have an iPhone. Personally, I didn't have any trouble with the Ultra using my iPhone. In fact, I was really impressed by the difference in quality as I was expecting the Ultra just to be a fancy looking Tone+ with "new" useless additions.There are complaints about the battery life of the new Ultra. iPhone users definitely seem unhappy with the Ultra. In fact, while the Tone+ claims to be compatible with Android, Apple and other Bluetooth enabled devices, the Ultra does not on the LG website. But again, I've had no problems with my Ultra on my iPhone or even on my iMac.While the Tone+ says it offers on/off vibration, the Ultra seems intent on peddling Google Voice Actions. Is Google Voice Actions the headphone’s version of Siri?The shape of the tips/ends of Ultra are noticeably different. Very Star Trekky. No, seriously, the shape reminds me of the Enterprise!Gone are the circular buttons. Instead, there is a small triangular button for play and an equal sign button for pause. On the other side, there is a button shaped like a telephone receiver. And the Rewind/Fas Forward buttons and Volume buttons are hidden away underneath on the sides of either ends. The earbud hollers are rounder.It comes with two on/off switches which are now inconveniently on the inside of your headset (facing your neck instead of facing out like on the Tone+). One switch turns on the ANC: Ambient Noise Cancellation aka “active noise cancellation.”The other is a power switch with an LED indicator tucked away discreetly unlike the way the “phone” button used to glow before. There’s no doubt this is sleeker and some would argue much better looking. I’m pretty attached to the way my Tone+ headphones look so I’m not sure how I feel about them.The earbuds are the same size but the seemingly minor change to the earbud holders (rounder, not squared in any direction) make them more snug in your ears…and a bit heavier.The ANC definitively makes the sound quality better. It gets a little getting used to the placement of the ANC switch, power switches and the volume and rewind and fast forward buttons. Especially because as I’ve mentioned they’re noticeably smaller and more discreet. I felt myself fumbling for the buttons and I have pretty small fingers so I can see someone with larger fingers fumbling even more.What really blew me away was the quality of the sound when I played some music off my iPhone. Wow. I felt like I was listening on quality headphones. The sound was incredibly rich! It felt like I was at an orchestra. The violins building on one side and the guitar and the drum in the other.The Tone+ does not even compare with regards to sound. The quality from my iMac wasn’t as good but it was pretty near my non-Bluetooth Bose headphones!So if you want some really cool sleek looking bluetooth headset with amazing sound quality, the Ultra is definitely worth the upgrade though the Tone+ are really awesome themselves if you don’t want to pay the extra cash just yet. This headset is really a middle ground between an awesome bluetooth headset for your phone and the gym and awesome bluetooth headphones...period.Enjoy! I'm now the proud owner of (2) Tone+ headsets and one Ultra...at least until my husband realizes how deliciously awesome the Ultra looks.
title: LG Electronics Tone Ultra (HBS-800) Bluetooth Stereo Headset - Retail Packaging - Black
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Headsets', 'Bluetooth Headsets']]

reviewText: I was curious to see how LG would follow up the incredible HBS-730 and HBS-700 models. While neither model would win any awards in an audiophile contest, their sound quality is more than adequate and between their excellent battery life and convenient, well thought out design, they have consistently become my go-to headset for most everything.The HBS-800 arrives on the market in early 2014 with two major hurdles: satisfied, picky users of previous models, and a stratospheric price.Here's what's different:Physically:- The shape is more organic and the neck band has a more contoured design to better sit around your neck.- The earbud cords are thicker and less fragile- The clips holding the earbud cords are stronger- The earbuds attach from the underside of the end of the tips, instead of the outside.- Instead of round buttons, they're shaped like a little phone and a play/pause logo.- The volume +/- and next/previous buttons have migrated from the top to the external side of the tips- The power button and activity light have moved to the inner side of the left tip- There is a new active noise cancellation mode activated by a switch on the inner side of the right tipOverall, most of these changes should have never been approved. There's nothing wrong with tampering with a beloved design as long as you improve on it, but most of these changes result in the headphones being slightly less pleasant to use. I suspect I will get used to them over time, but the 700/730 felt very natural and intuitive right away, the 800 does not.Electronically:- New active noise cancellation mode -- Not very convincing, but it's good at reducing battery life- Considerably better sound. This is the most welcome improvement on the 800, the sound quality is superb. Nice bass, delicate high end, warm mid ranges, the 800 is a delight.- Better microphone(s), quality of calls was already good and it is now top-notch- Two simultaneous bluetooth connections: the 800 can be paired and connected to two devices at the same time. If I remember correctly the 730 not only can't do this, but it requires re-pairing every time you want to switch devices. This makes using the 800 with a phone and tablet considerably simpler.Overall, I'd say the biggest disappointment is the jump in price, which is completely unjustified. If it were selling at around fifty smackeroos like its predecessors, the HBS-800 would be a no-brainer choice. At its current price of one thirty, the best thing is to wait a few months for the price to come down, and if you need headphones right away, get the 730. I think all the very negative reviews mostly come from people who like me loved their 700 and 730s, and feel the bizarre design choices and astronomical price point are a big let down. While I'm dinging the 800 one star because of its less convenient user interface, I think it's still the king of all bluetooth headsets and have no hesitation recommending it -- just don't pay retail!
title: LG Electronics Tone Ultra (HBS-800) Bluetooth Stereo Headset - Retail Packaging - Black
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Headsets', 'Bluetooth Headsets']]

reviewText: Okay, so. First off i'll admit I was influenced by the previous negative comments, especially comments from users who have had previous versions (HBS 700, 730, 750). I bought it regardless to give it a shot and so far after heavy use, i've learned to use it effectively and quite enjoy it. It isn't without faults but it still is quite good despite the reviews. This device was evaluated over 1 week paired to an LG-G2 and rocketfish USB adapter for PCPROs- smaller LED light- despite popular consensus the ANC DOES work and it will work even if you aren't listening to music. It will drain the battery quicker but its good to cancel high range external sound if i want to take a quick nap.- the dedicated call and play/pause keys make it a lot easier to figure out which side is which- contrary to popular consensus from users upgrading from the HBS 700 and 730 the overhang over the buds while it rests actually helps keep the buds in their place. i normally hide the headset under my collar while I work so my previous 700 had the buds constantly getting knocked out of their place while i worked. this hides them and makes it harder for them to come out by themselves- the magnet holding the buds in seems to be stronger compared to the 700. I can only comment from the 700 to the 800- much lighter than previous versions- more ergonomic around neck with slight curve in band- audio/call quality improved from 700CONs- the cables are shorter so i have to do a bit of maneuvering around my collar when i use it, not a massive deal but just an extra subconscious step.- battery life IS shorter compared the the 700. but don't let that deter you, it still has a massive battery life with the ANC off and while resting in standby compared to other brand headsets- the multi-access bluetooth seems to prioritize audio from desktop computers only giving preference to phones for calls, not a major issue but makes using the multi-access a pain- the range is diminished in windy areas limiting range to distances as short as 1.5ft in certain windy circumstances- the switches are a pain to operate. i became accustomed to slipping my finger over the switches but end up having to use my nail to operate on/off and ANC switches- this isn't necessarily a CON but i don't understand what the JBL audio gives to the system overall. all i can tell is that it allows you to notice equalizer changesI can understand the issues previous users have had to deal with while getting used to the device. It requires a learning curve that most people who are used to the previous device don't want to bother with. One such example not categorized above is how to return the buds to their resting cradles. instead of holding the buds i find its better to hold by the cables and slide from under and let the magnet pull it in.at the end of the day i say go for it, if its not for you Amazon has a brilliant return policy.
title: LG Electronics Tone Ultra (HBS-800) Bluetooth Stereo Headset - Retail Packaging - Black
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Headsets', 'Bluetooth Headsets']]

reviewText: Not worth the price Tag. For me i didnt get any difference among these 2 headsets in regard to sound quality.4 Price: I will buy this for the price of 69 but any thing more makes the upgrades insignificant.So i prefer hsb 730 for 40$ then 129 price of hsb 800.5 Battery: there is no difference in battery consumption. Both headsets gives 10 hours play back.6 Weight. May be this is lighter. but hsb 730 also never reminded me of weight. So even weight reduced but it may not makes any difference.
